content: CHICAGO (MarketWatch) — Shares of the following companies made notable moves in U.S. trading on Friday: Advancers Bio-Reference Laboratories Inc. BRLI   added 4%, erasing in part an 8% decline Thursday, when the company reported second-quarter results that topped most Wall Street forecasts. MarketWatch Week Ahead: Apple, Data From China Centene Corp. CNC, -1.14%  rallied 8% after it received notification from Ohio that it’ll be one of five health-care providers to be awarded a Medicaid contract in the state for 2013. China TranInfo Technology Corp. CTFO  jumped more than 18% after the transportation information company agreed to be bought by TransCloud Co. for $5.80 a share in cash. Molina Healthcare Inc. MOH, -2.25%  surged 26%, a sharp reversal after losing 31% in the previous session. The Long Beach, Calif.-based company said it won a case in Ohio, where a state agency reversed a decision and allowed it to continue to provide managed-care services for Medicaid beneficiaries in 2013. Late Wednesday, Molina withdrew its full-year profit forecast because of higher-than-expected costs in its Texas business. Optical Cable Corp. OCC, -4.67%  jumped 30% after the Roanoke, Va., fiber-optic company said second-quarter sales were the highest in company history, with a rise of 28% to $22.1 million. The company swung to a profit of 15 cents a share from a loss of 2 cents a share. Quiksilver Inc. ZQK  closed up by more than 12% after the company reported a narrower second-quarter loss late Thursday. Decliners ATP Oil & Gas Corp. ATPG   fell 9%. The Houston firm said Matt McCarroll stepped down after joining the company on June 1. McCarroll resigned as chief executive after ATP failed “to reach a mutually agreeable employment agreement,” the company said. McCarroll’s plan to buy 1 million shares of ATP Oil & Gas was rescinded. Reuters Progress Software Corp. PRGS, -3.77%  dropped 11%. The Bedford, Mass., technology company said it expects second-quarter revenue of $110 million to $115 million, below the estimate of $123.5 million in a survey of analysts by FactSet Research. The company expects adjusted second-quarter earnings of 17 cents to 19 cents a share, falling short of the analyst forecast of 26 cents a share. Thor Industries Inc. THO, -3.57%  shed more than 2% after the recreational-vehicle maker’s report of slightly weaker-than-expected third-quarter earnings marked by a decline in gross margins. Yum Brands YUM, -0.69% which operates the KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell restaurant chains, closed with a loss of 3%. The stock has come under pressure in recent sessions due to concerns about a possible slowdown in China. The selling in Yum came as McDonald’s Corp. MCD, +1.48%  reported earlier Friday weaker-than-forecast growth in same-store sales for May. content: Advancers Abercrombie & Fitch ANF, -0.41% shares surged 14% Wednesday after the company late Tuesday reported second-quarter net earnings of $65.7 million, or 72 cents a share, vs. $57.4 million, or a 63 cents a share, in the same period last year. See full story. ABM Industries ABM, -2.18% shares rose 6% after the company said it settled a World Trade Center legal dispute with insurer Zurich Financial Services for $80 million. The payment, due in September, will increase ABM's net income in the quarter ending Oct. 31 by roughly $45 million, or 90 cents a share. Shares of Celadon Group Inc. CLDN, +0.00% rallied 9% after Morgan Keegan upgraded the truckload carrier to outperform from market perform, citing "attractive" valuation, expectations of margin improvement and accelerating growth opportunities. Charming Shoppes Inc. CHRS, -4.07% shares climbed 11% said second-quarter net profit fell 17% to $32.6 million, or 24 cents a share, while net sales rose 10.8% to $763.4 million. Same-store sales for the company's retail brands rose 2% during the quarter. The company said its gross margin for the quarter was hit by higher levels of promotional activity and the inclusion of a full quarter of catalog operations, compared to just two months of operations in the year-ago quarter. The figures also include a $3.6 million, or 3 cents a share, expense related to the opening of new stores. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were expecting earnings of 25 cents a share on sales of $764 million. Leap Wireless International Inc. LEAP shares added 5.4% after the company said that it has entered into forward sale agreements for the sale of 5.6 million shares to affiliates of Goldman, Sachs & Co. and Citigroup Corporate and Investment Banking, who are offering 5.6 million shares in a public offering at $42.00 a share. The underwriters have been granted an option to purchase up to 840,000 shares to cover over-allotments. Leap intends to use the net proceeds, if any, for general corporate purposes and working capital. InnerWorkings INWK, -0.55% surged 16% in its stock market debut. See full story. Parlux Fragrances Inc. PARL shares soared 26% after the company said it has entered has entered into a letter of intent to sell its Perry Ellis fragrance rights to Victory International LLC. The letter of intent is subject to the execution of a definitive agreement, the Fort Lauderdale, Fla.-based company noted. The letter provides for Victory to pay Parlux a total of up to $140 million, $120 million for the fragrance rights and up to $20 million for inventory, the company said. Pep Boys PBY, -2.02% shares climbed 10% after the company reported second-quarter earnings from continuing operations of $1.47 million, or 3 cents a share, compared with $832,000, or a penny a share, during the year-ago period. Revenue at the Philadelphia-based auto parts retailer rose to $578.6 million from $577.4 million a year ago. Shares of SpectraLink Corp. SLNK shot up 8% after Morgan Keegan upgraded the workplace wireless telephony company to outperform from market perform, saying the company's operational outlook makes the current valuation "compelling." Talbots Inc. TLB, +0.00% shares gained 11% after the company said it swung to a second-quarter loss, hurt by acquisition costs and stock option expenses. The Hingham, Mass.-based retailer posted a net loss of $3.86 million, or 7 cents a share. In the year-ago period it earned $18.88 million, or 35 cents a share. Net sales rose to $571.4 million from $449.6 million. Analysts, on average, expected it to post a loss of 8 cents a share on revenue of $576 million, according to Thomson First Call. Total company same-store sales rose 1.3% for the second quarter. Decliners Casella Waste Systems Inc. CWST, +0.38% shares fell 10% Wednesday after it reported preliminary fiscal first-quarter results. The Rutland, Va.-based company said it expects a first-quarter loss of 2 cents to 4 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are forecasting a per-share profit of 7 cents. Casella said its results were impact by record rainfall in the northeast. The company added that its overall first-quarter revenue is on track, with the exception of its southeastern region. Casella also forecast fiscal 2007 earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization of $113 million to $117 million. Daktronics Inc. DAKT, -1.70% shares tumbled 28% after the company posted net earnings of $5 million, or 12 cents a share, for its fiscal first quarter 2007, compared with earnings of $4.6 million, or 11 cents a share, the year earlier. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were on average expecting earnings of 16 cents. Net sales rose to $92.2 million from $72.3 million the year earlier. The Brookings, S.D.-based company said it expects earnings for its fiscal second-quarter to come in a range of 13 to 18 cents per share. The Thomson First Call forecast is for earnings per share of 18 cents. Shares of Daktronics were recently at $21.86, down $9.02 in pre-market activity. Golfsmith International Holdings Inc. GOLF, -1.47% shares lost 12% reported a second-quarter net loss of $7.94 million, or 73 cents a share. During the same period a year ago, the Austin, Texas-based company posted net earnings of $6 million, or 60 cents a share. Mills Corp. MLS, -1.38% shares lost 20% said in a filing late Tuesday that it has terminated Mark Ettenger as president of the company effective Aug. 11. Mills said Ettenger remains employed at the firm, but did not specify his role in the filing. Additionally, the company said James Napoli, executive vice president of leasing, has delivered notice he will terminate his employment effective on or before Oct. 27. Mills is being investigated by the SEC over accounting problems and has indicated it is exploring strategic options including a potential sale of all or part of the company. Shares of Optical Cable Corp. OCC, -4.67% fell 9.7% after the company rejected an unsolicited proposal from Superior Essex Inc. to acquire the company for $6 a share. The proposal is the same as a private proposal from Superior Essex first received by Optical Cable on Aug. 1, which was considered by the board and rejected as financially inadequate, the company noted. Shanda Interactive Entertainment Ltd. SNDA lost 5.3% after the company reported second-quarter net earnings of 133.6 million yuan ($16.7 million), or 1.86 yuan (24 cents) per American Depositary Share, compared with 223 million yuan, or 3.06 yuan per ADS, during the year-ago period. Tween Brands TWB shares fell 5.3% after the company reported a 49% jump in second-quarter earnings and backed its previous full-year forecast. See full story. content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Optical Cable Corp. OCC, -4.67% were down almost 6% at $8.80 in afternoon trading on Wednesday. Earlier, Optical Cable said that it received an unsolicited and contingent proposal from Superior Essex Inc. spsx to acquire the company for $6 a share. The proposal is the same as a private proposal from Superior Essex first received by Optical Cable on Aug. 1, which was considered by the board and rejected as financially inadequate, the company noted. "The board views Superior Essex's proposal as grossly inadequate and opportunistic, and has concluded that seeking to negotiate a combination with Superior Essex at this time would be incompatible with, and could in fact interfere with, the course of action we are pursuing," the company said in a statement.
title: Optical Cable rejects bid from Superior Essex; shares fall

content: Advancers Bausch & Lomb Inc. BOL shares ended Friday with a 5.9% gain. The company said it will delay the filing of its Form 10-K with the Securities and Exchange Commission, and also said it has so far found evidence that from 2002 to 2005, its Korean unit engaged in improper vision care-related sales practices and it subsequently expects that its previously reported expected restatement of prior period financial statements will also include revenue recognition adjustments from the unit. It sees its previously reported net sales for the first and second quarters of 2005 lowered by a cumulative total of $1.4 million and net sales for the period 2002 through 2004 lowered by $7.9 million. Additional revenue recognition adjustments relating to refractive laser sales in certain foreign subsidiaries and for certain vision care transactions with a single distributor in Thailand will further affect Bausch & Lomb's results. It sees net sales for the first and second quarters of 2005 being reduced by $1.4 million and net sales for the period 2003 to 2004 lowered by a $1.9 million. Shares of CBRL Group Inc. CBRL added 6.1% after the company said its board approved a restructuring plan that includes divesting its Logan's Roadhouse business, a modified "Dutch Auction" tender offer stock buyback plan of up to $800 million, and financing of up to $1.25 billion by Wachovia Securities. The offering for Logan's is expected to be completed on or before Sept. 30. The offering is expected to be conducted by a syndicate of underwriters pursuant to a restructuring plan announced today by CBRL. The amount of common stock to be sold has not yet been determined. See full story. EOn Communications Corp. EONC shares surged 19% after the company reported second-quarter net earnings of $607,000, or 5 cents a share. In the same period last year, the company reported a net loss of $528,000, or 4 cents a share. Revenue at the Atlanta-based company rose 16% to $2.96 million from $2.55 million. Lightbridge Inc. LTBG stock tacked on 5% after the company was upgraded to buy from hold at Wedbush Morgan. Nastech Pharmaceutical Co. NSTK shares surged 10.4% after the company was upgraded to buy from hold at Needham & Co. Peregrine Pharmaceuticals Inc. PPHM shares rose 5.9% after the company said its board approved a stockholder rights agreement with a 15% trigger. The Tustin, Calif., drugmaker said it's not adopting the plan in response to any known offer to acquire the company. Shares of Pioneer Cos. PONR rallied 10.3% after the company said fourth-quarter net income was $11.1 million, or 94 cents a share, compared with $4.54 million, or 41 cents a share, during the same period last year. The chlorine manufacturer said quarterly revenue was $131 million, up from $112 million last year. Rambus Inc. RMBS stock gained 5.6% after the company signed a technology license agreement with IBM IBM As part of the deal, IBM will build broadband processors and chips based on Rambus' processor bus and memory interface technologies. Shares of RF Industries Ltd. RFIL surged 14.3% after the San Diego-based maker of radio frequency coaxial connectors posted a fourth-quarter profit of $265,000, or 7 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $206,000, or 5 cents a share. Sales rose 18% in the latest three months to $3.4 million from $2.9 million in the same period a year earlier. The company said lower general and administrative expenses offset reduced gross margins in the quarter. RTI International Inc. RTI stock ended higher by 6.9% after the Niles, Ohio-based titanium producer said its Fabrication and Distribution Group unit signed a multi-year deal to supply extruded and fully machined value-added structural titanium components and services to Kawasaki Heavy Industries Ltd. RTI said the deal is in support of production of the Boeing 787 aircraft program. SBA Communications Corp. SBAC shares closed up 10.6% after the company agreed to acquire AAT Communications Corp. for roughly $1 billion in cash and stock. The consideration consists of $634 million in cash and the issuance of 17.06 million SBA common shares. Boca Raton, Fla.-based SBA expects the deal to close in the second quarter. In conjunction with the deal, SBA plans to start a tender offer for its remaining 9 3/4% senior discount notes and 8 1/2% senior notes. AAT is the fifth largest independent wireless communications tower operator in the U.S. with 1,855 owned tower sites and an additional 250 revenue-producing managed sites located in 44 states, SBA said. The company also gave a pro forma outlook for fiscal 2006 for total revenue of $355.5 million and $381.5 million. The pro forma estimate assumes closing of the AAT deal as of Jan. 1. See full story. Sirius Satellite Radio Inc. SIRI shares gained 8.4% after the company signed exclusive deals with Audi and Volkswagen. Shares of Sunesis Pharmaceuticals Inc. SNSS advanced 11.4% after the company said it's inked an agreement to raise roughly $45 million through a private placement. The company agreed to sell 7.25 million shares of its common stock in the offering. The deal also includes warrants to purchase an additional 2.17 million shares of its common stock for a price of $6.21 each. Tektronix Inc. TEK stock surged 12.6% after the company reported fiscal third-quarter net earnings of $26.5 million, or 32 cents a share, vs. $26.8 million, or 30 cents a share, in the year-ago period. There were 83.3 million shares outstanding compared with 90.7 million last year. Excluding items, the company's profit came in at 37 cents a share compared with 31 cents a share a year ago. Revenue at the Beaverton, Ore.-based provider of technology measurement solutions rose to $262.1 million from $256.3 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast earnings of 33 cents a share on revenue of $263 million. Shares of William Lyon Homes WLS rocketed higher by 30.8% after the company said Chairman and Chief Executive General William Lyon launched an offer to buy all remaining shares of the company at $93 each. The Newport Beach, Calif., company said the offer expires April 13. General Lyon owns 48% of the common shares of William Lyon Homes and controls 50.4% of the total voting power of the company. General Lyon and various trusts own a combined 74.5% of William Lyon Homes common shares outstanding. See full story. World Fuel Services Corp. INT stock rose 10% after the company posted a fourth-quarter profit of $12 million, or 42 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $11.2 million, or 47 cents a share. The Miami-based marine and aviation fuel marketer said its decision to repatriate $40 million in foreign earnings in December resulted in an additional tax expense for the year of $2.8 million, or 11 cents a share. Revenue rose in the latest three months to $2.53 billion from $1.79 billion in the same period a year earlier. Decliners Cray Inc. CRAY shares ended Friday lower by 10.8% after the company said its 2004 loss could be widened up to $3.3 million, and its revenue reduced, if it is determined that revenue from one of the supercomputer maker's product development contracts was recognized incorrectly. Given the review into prior results, the company has delayed the filing of its 2005 annual report. On a preliminary basis, Cray said it lost $9 million, or 10 cents a share in the fourth quarter, and $64 million, or 73 cents a share in 2005. Revenue was $65 million in the fourth quarter and $201 million for the year. For 2006, the company expects revenue will grow 5% to 15%. Shares of Merge Technologies Inc. MRGE tumbled 11.8% after the Milwaukee-based developer of medical imaging software delayed the filing of its Form 10-K for fiscal 2006 as it works to resolve revenue recognition and tax accounting matters stemming from its merger with Cedara Software Corp. in June. The company also cited an investigation of certain anonymous complaints for the delay. Merge added that it now anticipates reporting material weaknesses in its internal controls over financial reporting, and that it has suspended the issuance of shares of its common stock upon exchange of shares in Merge/CedaraExchangeCo Ltd. until further notice. Merge said its financial results for the past two quarters ended on June 30 and Sept. 30 respectively should no longer be relied upon, and that it will need to increase its tax liability as related to the Cedara deal by roughly $3.8 million for the June quarter. Mills Corp. MLS stock gave back 5.1% after the company was downgraded to sell from hold at Citigroup. "Our confidence in Mills' net asset value is low and deteriorating, given complex and un-audited financials, unknown terms of JVs, huge development pipeline and considerably high leverage," the broker said. Shares of Optical Cable Corp. OCCF sank 10.6% after Roanoke, Va., provider of fiber optic cable products reported a first-quarter loss of $220,000, or 4 cents a share, slightly wider than a year-ago loss of $223,000, or 4 cents a share. Sales fell 11.4% in the latest three months to $9.9 million from $11.1 million in the same period a year earlier. The company said it doesn't believe the performance in the first quarter is indicative of results for the rest of the year. Optical Cable said first-quarter results were hurt by decreases in sales in a number of its specialty markets, and short-term production inefficiencies. The company also said it reorganized its sales department in the current quarter, a move it expects to result in costs of about $285,000. RightNow Technologies Inc. RNOW shares lost 5.1% after the company was downgraded to neutral from buy at Pacific Growth Equities due to concerns about future growth at the company. Synagro Technologies Inc. SYGR stock gave back 5.7% after the company was downgraded to sector performer at CIBC World Markets. The firm, which also dropped its price target on the stock to $5 from $5.50, cited the company's disappointing financial report for the fourth quarter. UTStarcom Inc. UTSI shares ended the session with a 6.1% loss after the company predicted it would fall into a loss for 2005 despite an expected 9.3% rise in revenue. The news was delivered along with word the company would delay its 2005 annual filing with regulators. UTStarcom, which makes networking infrastructure systems, predicted a loss of $462 million for the year, reversing a profit of $73.4 million the previous year. It pegged revenue at $2.95 billion, up from $2.7 billion a year ago. Shares of ViroPharma Inc. VPHM plunged 33.2% on speculation that its lead drug Vancocin could be facing generic competition sooner than expected. See full story. WorldSpace Inc. WRSP shares sank 22.8% after the Silver Spring, Md., provider of satellite digital radio services reported a fourth-quarter loss of $33.2 million, or 90 cents a share, on revenue of $4.4 million. In the same period a year earlier, the company lost $418.2 million, or $71.45 a share, due to the inclusion of stock compensation expenses as well as a number of costs related to restructuring activities. The average estimate of two analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a loss of 55 cents a share in the December period. content: Stocks to watch General Electric GE, -2.00% highlights Friday's earnings calendar with analysts expecting the mega-conglomerate to post a fourth-quarter profit of 45 cents a share on revenue exceeding $36 billion. Drugmaker Abbot Labs ABT, -1.60% is also due out, pegged by Wall Street to bring in 65 cents a share on 5.3 billion in sales. Others set to report include Rediff.com REDF KeyCorp KEY, -1.74% and a host of smaller banks. Cree CREE, -3.34% rode its second-quarter profit to a 6-percent gain in relatively busy after-hours action late Thursday. The chipmaker beat analyst targets, citing a strong performance from its Light Emitting Diode business. Networking gear maker Juniper JNPR, -1.11% doubled its net per-share profit for the fourth quarter as sales turned in an "exceptionally strong" performance. Shares charged 14 percent higher following the report and topped the Island ECN most active list after the close. Rambus RMBS, -1.49% rose 3 percent to $34.60 after the memory chip designer reported fourth-quarter earnings of 8 cents a share and revenue of $32.4 million. Rambus had projected sales between $29 million and $31 million. Shares of Sun Microsystems SUNW, -2.11% edged up 1 percent in late trading and should remain busy in Friday's regular session. The server giant reported a second-quarter net loss of $125 million, or 4 cents a share, on revenue of $2.88 billion. Wall Street pegged Sun to lose 5 cents a share on sales of $2.75 billion. During the same period a year ago, Sun lost $2.28 billion, or 72 cents a share on $2.92 billion. See full story. Texas Instruments TXN, -1.85% announced Chairman and CEO Tom Engibous, 50, will pass on his chief executive duties to Chief Operating Officer Rich Templeton, 45, as part of a planned, four-month succession plan. See full story. Transgenomic shares TBIO tacked on more than a quarter of their value to $2.90 after the company said it inked a deal which will allow Transgenomic to distribute Nanogen's NanoChip Molecular Biology Workstation in some European cities. Transmeta shares TMTA fell 4 percent after the company said it narrowed its fourth-quarter loss to 15 cents a share from 16 cents a year ago. The chipmaker expects its mobile computing arm to drive growth in 2004. Advancers Agilysys AGYS, -2.68% jumped 88 cents, or 7 percent, to close at $12.93 after the business software firm raised its fiscal 2004 earnings outlook after a better-than-expected third quarter. Cleveland-based Agilysys said it now expects earnings of 22 to 24 cents per share for 2004, up from a prior forecast of 16 to 20 cents. For the third quarter, the company is expecting 29 to 31 cents a share, against an earlier 26 to 28 cents. Bank One ONE, -1.86% rose $5.20, or 11.5 percent, to end the day at $50.42. The company agreed to be acquired by J.P. Morgan JPM, -1.65% for about $60 billion in the biggest financial deal on Wall Street in six years, creating a financial services giant second only to Citigroup C, +0.25% in total assets, the companies confirmed Wednesday. The combination will create a banking group with almost $1.1 trillion in assets. See full story. Fairchild Semiconductor FCS, +1.96% shares gained $1.94, or nearly 8 percent, to finish at $27.80 after the company said fourth-quarter sales rose 12 percent on the third quarter to $369.2 million and were up 4 percent on the year. Analysts forecast revenue for the quarter at $359.03 million, according to Reuters Research. The company reported net income of $5.3 million or 4 cents a share, including a charge for in-process research and development related to the purchase of Raytheon's non-military RF components business. Inter Parfums IPAR, -2.23% shares leapt $2.63, or 12 percent, to $24.14 after the company beat its own fourth quarter sales target and raised its outlook for 2004. The New York-based perfume maker said fourth-quarter sales totaled $49.4 million, boosting full-year sales to $185.6 million, up 42 percent from a year ago and ahead of its own forecast of $182 million. The company said it now expects 2004 sales of $15.8 million, against an earlier forecast of $15 million, assuming the dollar remains at current levels and excluding the impact of a pending acquisition of Nickel S.A. Lucent Technologies LU gained 40 cents, or 10 percent, to end at $4.47. Lehman Bros. upgraded the telecommunications equipment maker to "overweight" from "equal weight," citing recent evidence of an increasingly improving sales outlook. Analyst Steven Levy said Verizon Wireless' planned $1 billion network upgrade could benefit Lucent, as can SBC's SBC, -1.09% higher 2004 capital spending budget and its contract wins with Chinese telecom carriers. He raised his year-end 2004 stock price target to $4.50 from $3.50, his respective 2004 and 2005 earnings estimates to 11 and 15 cents a share from 8 and 12 cents, and his 2004 and 2004 revenue forecasts to $8.9 billion and $9.3 billion, respectively, from $8.7 billion and $9.1 billion. Marvel Enterprises MVL, +1.31% rose $2.87, or 9.6 percent, to close at $32.65 after the company named Ames Kirshen manager of game development, a new position. Kirshen, who has six years of experience in the video game projects with Warner Bros. and DC Comics, will lead a "small group" that will oversee the development of video games based upon Marvel characters. Mercury Computer Systems MRCY, -0.89% advanced $3.65, or 13.5 percent, to $30.61. The company posted earnings of 17 cents per share for the fiscal second quarter ended Dec. 31, down from the prior year's 29 cents but better than the 15 cents expected by two analysts surveyed by Reuters Research. Quarterly revenue totaled $40.6 million, down 15 percent from the prior year. Mercury Computer's backlog grew by $11.3 million over the course of the latest quarter, reaching $74.7 million. The company also projected earnings of 26 cents to 30 cents per share for the current quarter, assuming revenue improves to an estimated range of $45 million to $48 million. And for all of fiscal 2004, Mercury Computer sees earnings of $1.00 to $1.05 per share, higher than the consensus of 86 cents. RadioShack RSH, -0.07% added $2.14, or 7 percent, to $32.49 after the consumer electronics retailer boosted its earnings outlook for the fourth quarter. See full story. Teradyne TER, -3.59% gained $3.38, or 12.7 percent, to $30 after the company reported fourth-quarter sales and a bottom-line result Wednesday that beat Wall Street expectations, due to a 45-percent spike in net orders. Boston-based Teradyne, a maker of test equipment used to make computer chips, posted a net loss of $11.5 million, or 6 cents a share. The company had lost $423.8 million, or $2.31 a share, in the fourth quarter of 2002. See full story. Decliners Apple Computer AAPL, -0.57% shares lost $1.35, or $5.6, to close at $22.85 despite news that the company beat quarterly analyst estimates with better Macintosh and iPod sales that boosted revenue by 36 percent. Apple said it earned $63 million, or 17 cents a share in its fiscal first quarter. In the same period a year earlier, Apple posted a loss of $8 million, or 2 cents a share. Sales rose to $2 billion from $1.47 billion in the same period last year. Apple recorded an after-tax gain of $3 million related to a stock sale that lifted earnings by a penny a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for a profit of 15 cents a share on sales of $1.93 billion. See full story. Huffy Corp. HUF, +0.00% fell 50 cents, or 9 percent, to $5.05 after the company said it expects fourth-quarter losses to be wider than previously expected due to lower gross margins in its basketball backboard and in-line skate businesses and higher expenses in its Gen-X business. The sporting goods company said it negotiated an amendment to its credit agreements, including revising financial covenants to reflect its current outlook. Meanwhile, sales for the quarter are expected to be in line with expectations at $120 million to $125 million. Looking ahead, the company expects earnings of 22 to 27 cents a share and sales of $450 million to $460 million in 2004. National Processing NAP, +1.98% lost $3.23, or 13.5 percent, to finish at $20.72. The credit and debit card processor reported fourth-quarter earnings that met expectations, but provided a 2004 earnings outlook that was below forecasts. Net income for the quarter ending December was $14.8 million, or 28 cents a share, up from 27 cents a share in the year-earlier period, and revenue rose 15 percent to $135.5 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 28 cents a share and revenue of $127.6 million, on average. For 2004, the company expects earnings to be 90 to 95 cents a share due to an unfavorable merchant contract-pricing environment. Optical Cable OCC, -4.67% shares sank 74 cents, or 9.5 percent, to $7.09 after the Roanoke, Va., firm reported fourth-quarter earnings of $405,000, or 7 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $326,000, or 5 cents per share. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a mean estimate for the company's results. Sales rose 7.5 percent in the latest three months to $11.3 million from $10.6 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, however, the company said it remains "cautiously optimistic" about future net sales, and that it remains "unclear when our markets will begin to show sustainable growth." Shares of Remington Oil & Gas REM, -1.04% tumbled $1.71, or 8.2 percent, to $19.14 after A.G. Edwards dropped its assessment of the company to "sell" from "buy." The firm cited recent indications of lower than expected rates of production and reserve growth, and noted the company has had trouble overcoming steep declines in the Gulf of Mexico, and finding significant new sources of oil and gas reserves of late. Video Display VIDE, -6.67% shares slumped $1.97, or 15 percent, to end the day at $11.26 after the company reported a slight decline in third quarter sales to $18.1 million from $18.2 million. The Atlanta-based maker of display solutions for military, medical and industrial use said it swung to a profit of 8 cents a share from a loss of $1.03 a year ago. The year-earlier figure includes pretax write-downs and write-offs on inventories and manufacturing assets stemming from the closure of six facilities. title: Juniper, Sun, TI and more

content: Zimmer Holdings boosts Q4 outlook (4:37 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Medical device maker Zimmer Holdings said Thursday it expects to beat Thomson First Call analysts' average earnings estimate for its fourth quarter 2003. The company expects quarterly to reach about $700 million, up from a previous estimate of $666 million, and earnings per share excluding charges to be 44 cents, 4 cents higher than average estimate. Zimmer rose 66 cents to close at $70.66 Thursday. Rambus Q4 earns 8c, sales $32.4 mln (4:35 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Rambus RMBS, -1.41% reported fourth-quarter earnings of 8 cents a share and revenue of $32.4 million. The designer of memory chips had projected sales between $29 million and $31 million. Juniper nearly doubles profit on sales surge (4:25 PM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) - Juniper Networks JNPR, -1.07% on Thursday said profit nearly doubled from a year earlier as sales turned in an "exceptionally strong" performance during the fourth quarter. In the three months ended Dec. 31, the company said it earned $14.7 million, or 4 cents a share, compared with income of $8.5 million, or 2 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose 33 percent to $207 million from $155.3 million a year ago. In the prior quarter, Juniper generated $172.1 million in revenue. Excluding onetime items, the company posted profit of $27.7 million, or 7 cents a share, compared with $2.7 million, or 1 cent, a year earlier. Analysts surveyed by Thomson One Analytics had expected Juniper to earn 5 cents a share on sales of $183 million. Sun Micro posts Q2 loss of $125 million (4:06 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Sun Microsystems SUNW, -2.11% on Thursday reported a second-quarter net loss of $125 million, or 4 cents a share, on revenue of $2.88 billion. Analysts surveyed by Reuters Research estimated Sun would lose 5 cents a share on sales of $2.75 bilion. During the same period a year ago, Sun lost $2.28 billion, or 72 cents a share on $2.92 billion. Rambus reports after close, analyst seeks court clarity (2:52 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Memory chip designer Rambus RMBS, -1.41% reports financial results after the market closes on Thursday. Analyst Erach Desai with American Technology Research wants additional clarity regarding the company's legal battles, specifically its views on being able to proceed with only four of its infringement claims in an appeal against Infineon IFX, -1.11% Rambus shares slipped 1.8 percent at $33.57. Deckers Outdoor boosts view due to Ugg boot's success (2:42 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Deckers Outdoor DECK, -2.03% jumped almost 12 percent to $21 in late action. After Wednesday's closing bell, the fashion footwear firm raised its financial outlook for 2004 to reflect heightened demand for its Ugg boot product line. The company now sees earnings of $1.02 to $1.06 per share for 2004 on sales of between $133 million and $140 million. Deckers previously projected earnings of 92 to 96 cents per share on sales ranging from $126 million to $132 million. Due to short-term production capacity constraints, Deckers believes the majority of the increased business will occur in the second, third, and fourth quarters. The current average view of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for a profit of 96 cents per share for the year. First Albany issued a research note following the company's presentation at an investment conference Thursday, saying Deckers announced a new Ugg license for its handbags and leather goods, and that it's in talks with Nordstrom JWN, -1.03% to sell Ugg products. "Expanded licensing of brands and new product releases are catalysts that we believe can drive the stock higher over the next six to nine months. Other catalysts include accelerating sales and the de-leveraging of the company's balance sheet," the firm said. First Albany reiterated its "buy" rating and $24 price target on Deckers shares. Danaher hits 52-week high on Q4 earnings view (2:07 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Danaher DHR, -1.51% shares rose more than 3 percent to $93.19 after the company expects earnings for the fourth quarter to meet or slightly exceed a range of $1.00 to $1.04 per share. This range reflects the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a profit of 91 to 95 cents per share and an expected gain of 9 cents per share related to the curtailment of the company's cash balance pension plan. The Washington maker of process and environmental control equipment anticipates revenue will increase about 17 percent on a year-over-year basis for the quarter. Earlier in the session, the stock hit a 52-week high of $93.22. Sell-off for The Singing Machine (1:41 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of The Singing Machine SMD, +4.76% plunged more than 30 percent to $1.40 in afternoon trades. After Wednesday's closing bell, the Coconut Creek, Fla., maker of karaoke machines forecast a loss of at least $4 million for the third quarter, and said this performance would put it in violation of the net worth covenant of its credit agreement. The company, which added it could be violation of other covenants as well, sees revenue of about $27 million for the period. The loss estimate includes at least $2.6 million in inventory and other write-downs. Optical Cable drops in wake of Q4 report (12:58 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Optical Cable OCC, -4.67% shares sank more than 13 percent to $6.80 in midday action. After Wednesday's closing bell, the Roanoke, Va., firm reported fourth-quarter earnings of $405,000, or 7 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $326,000, or 5 cents per share. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a mean estimate for the company's results. Sales rose 7.5 percent in the latest three months to $11.3 million from $10.6 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, however, the company said it remains "cautiously optimistic" about future net sales, and that it remains "unclear when our markets will begin to show sustainable growth." Nat'l Processing leads NYSE decliners on 2004 outlook (11:08 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - National Processing NAP, +2.25% slumped $3.36, or 14 percent, to $20.59, and topped the NYSE's percentage decliners list, after the credit and debit card processor reported fourth-quarter earnings that met expectations, but provided a 2004 earnings outlook that was below forecasts. Net income for the quarter ending December was $14.8 million, or 28 cents a share, up from 27 cents a share in the year-earlier period, and revenue rose 15 percent to $135.5 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 28 cents a share and revenue of $127.6 million, on average. For 2004, the company expects earnings to be 90 to 95 cents a share due to an unfavorable merchant contract pricing environment. U.S. mortgage rates tumble in latest week (10:46 AM ET) CHICAGO (CBS.MW) -- U.S. mortgage rates fell sharply in the week ending Thursday, responding to a decline in bond rates in the last few days. Freddie Mac FRE, +0.00% said Thursday that the national average interest rate on a 30-year mortgage dropped to 5.66 percent from 5.87 percent a week earlier. The rate on the 15-year loan, a popular refinancing choice, slid below 5 percent at 4.97 percent. One-year, Treasury-indexed, adjustable-rate mortgages also fell, averaging 3.62 percent versus 3.76 percent a week ago. TriZetto tumbles on warning of Q4 loss (10:46 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Shares of TriZetto Group TZIX tumbled $1.19, or 17 percent, to $5.75 after saying late Wednesday that it expected to report a fourth-quarter loss, excluding special items, of 5 cents a share, while analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting a profit of 5 cents a share, as certain software contracts failed to close during the quarter. The stock hit a 9-month low of $5 earlier in the session. The healthcare information technology company said revenue would be $66 million, below analyst forecasts of $79.3 million. The company added that Mike Sunderland would relinquish his role as chief financial officer to take on a new role. Jim Malone, formerly the CFO of IMS Health, will replace Sunderland as CFO later in the first quarter. Looking ahead, TriZetto expects 2004 revenue to grow 7 to 12 percent over 2003 to $290 million to $305 million, below current analyst projections of $332.2 million. Dollar now at 'reasonable levels,' manufacturers say (10:22 AM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- The U.S. dollar is no longer tremendously overvalued, the head of the National Association of Manufacturers said Thursday. "The dollar has come down to more reasonable levels," said Jerry Jasinowski, president of the NAM and a chief critic of the U.S. strong dollar policy. "The decline in the dollar has been good for the American economy," he said. But China has not yet acted to free the yuan from the artificial peg that harms U.S. manufacturers, he said. NAM and others are still pursuing legal action that would impose sanctions on Chinese imports. Freeing the yuan would not lead to a run on the dollar that would force U.S. interest rates higher, NAM's Frank Vargo said. "U.S. monetary policy is set in Washington, not Beijing," Vargo said. QLogic slides as Q3 rev. and Q4 outlook disappoints (10:03 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Shares of QLogic QLGC, +0.12% fell $3.49, or 6.9 percent, to $46.87 after the disk drive maker reported late-Wednesday fiscal third-quarter earnings that topped expectations, but revenue that fell a bit short. Net income for the quarter ending December, excluding non-recurring items was $37.9 million, or 39 cents a share, up from 31 cents a share in the year-earlier period, and revenue rose 20 percent to $137.1 million. Analysts surveyed by Reuters Research had been expecting earnings of 37 cents a share and revenue of $137.6 million, on average. Merrill Lynch analyst Shelby Seyrafi said the company's fourth-quarter revenue growth outlook of 1 to 3 percent sequentially was also a concern, given it was below the "more typical" growth forecasts of 2 to 5 percent the company had been providing in prior quarters. Rowan's Q4 earns fall short of expectations (9:29 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Rowan RDC, -2.25% reported fourth-quarter net income of $4.4 million, or 5 cents a share, up from a loss of 3 cents a share in the year-earlier period, but below the average analyst estimate compiled by Reuters Research of 7 cents a share. Total revenue rose 33 percent to $195.75 million, topping analyst expectations of $189.5 million. The oil services company said it was "optimistic" that an improvement in revenue, utilization and average day rates at the end of the year would continue into 2004. The stock closed Wednesday down 78 cents at $23.32. TCF Financial's Q4, full-year earnings miss estimates (9:21 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - TCF Financial TCB, +0.00% reported fourth-quarter and full-year earnings that missed expectations as unexpectedly low interest rates led to a high-level of mortgage loan prepayments. Separately, the financial services firm said it raised its quarterly dividend by a nickel a share to 37.5 cents a share. Net income was $59.5 million, or 86 cents a share for the quarter and $215.9 million, or $3.05 for the year, vs. year-earlier earnings of 82 cents and $3.15, respectively. Analysts surveyed by Reuters Research had been expecting earnings of 88 cents a share for the quarter and $3.07 for the year. The financial services company said net interest margins fell as loan yields fell faster than costs could be cut. Total assets dropped 7 percent during the year to $883 million. The stock closed Wednesday unchanged at $49.79. McDonald's sees Q4 EPS in line (9:11 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- McDonald's MCD, +1.20% said it expects to earn 10 cents per share in the fourth quarter, including a charge of 25 cents per share. Without the charge, the component of the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -1.27% will meet the EPS forecast of 35 cents in a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. The company said its fourth-quarter sales performance was "strong," with global systemwide sales rising 17 percent in December and 16.6 percent in the fourth quarter. U.S. comparable sales gained 12.2 percent in December. Shares of McDonald's rose 43 cents to $25.07 on Wednesday. IBM reiterates 2004 EPS target (8:55 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- International Business Machines IBM, -1.59% shares are rallying $5.80, or 6 percent, to $96.11 as the company issued upbeat comments on the coming fiscal year on its conference call. Chief Financial Officer John R. Joyce said Wall Street's current earnings per share forecast of $4.88 for 2004 is "reasonable." Joyce told analysts on the Dow component's conference call that 2004 will mark the beginning of a positive trend in the information technology business. IBM is expecting revenue growth in 2004 to be about 1 percent ahead of Wall Street estimates as the company benefits from a weak dollar overseas. IBM reiterated its goal of high single digit percentage growth in revenue and low double digit percentage growth in earnings per share. Huffy's Q4 losses to be wider than expected (8:47 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Huffy Corp. HUF, +0.00% said it expects fourth-quarter losses to be wider than previously expected due to lower gross margins in its basketball backboard and in-line skate businesses and higher expenses in its Gen-X business. The sporting goods company said it negotiated an amendment to its credit agreements, including revising financial covenants to reflect its current outlook. Meanwhile, sales for the quarter are expected to be in line with expectations at $120 million to $125 million. Looking ahead, the company expects earnings of 22 to 27 cents a share and sales of $450 million to $460 million in 2004. The stock closed Wednesday up a nickel at $5.55. North Fork Bank fourth-quarter net falls (8:44 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- North Fork Bank NFB reported fourth-quarter earnings of $102.4 million, or 68 cents per share, down from $107.3 million, or 67 cents per share in the year-ago period. The Long Island-based regional bank beat the forecast of 64 cents per share in a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. The company cited further improvement in its net interest margin, "significant" loan and deposit growth and progress on a recent acquisition. Shares rose 88 cents to $41.72 on Wednesday. Commerce Bancorp Q4 net jumps 40% (8:30 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Commerce Bancorp CBH, +0.11% reported fourth-quarter net income of $56.6 million, or 71 cents per share, compared with $40.6 million, or 57 cents per share in the year-ago period. Revenue jumped 32 percent to $303 million. The Cherry Hill, N.J. lender beat the forecast of 69 cents per share in a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. The company reiterated its EPS target of 20 percent growth. Shares of Commerce Bank rose $1.85 to $55 on Wednesday. Charles River Q4 EPS in line; sees 15%-20% '04 growth (8:29 AM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- Charles River Associates CRAI, -1.38% said it earned 28 cents per share for the fourth quarter ended Nov. 30, up from the prior year's 25 cents and matching the three-analyst consensus compiled by Reuters Research. Revenue reached $39 million from $36.4 million in the final three months of fiscal 2002. Full-year earnings were $1.16 per share on revenue of $163.5 million for fiscal 2003, up from fiscal 2002's 91 cents earned on revenue of $130.7 million. As for fiscal 2004, the Boston-based consulting firm is projecting growth at 15 to 20 percent, with revenue growing at the lower end of this range and profits growing at the higher end. Charles River shares closed Wednesday's trading at $37.03, down 28 cents. Mercury Computer Q2 profit better than Street consensus (7:52 AM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- Mercury Computer Systems MRCY, -0.91% posted earnings of 17 cents per share for the fiscal second quarter ended Dec. 31, down from the prior year's 29 cents but better than the 15 cents expected by two analysts surveyed by Reuters Research. Quarterly revenue totaled $40.6 million, down 15 percent from the prior year. Mercury Computer's backlog grew by $11.3 million over the course of the latest quarter, reaching $74.7 million. The company also projected earnings of 26 cents to 30 cents per share for the current quarter, assuming revenue improves to an estimated range of $45 million to $48 million. And for all of fiscal 2004, Mercury Computer sees earnings of $1.00 to $1.05 per share, higher than the consensus of 86 cents. Mercury Computer shares ended unchanged at $26.96 on Wednesday. Extreme Networks Q2 loss narrows, meets expectations (7:48 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Extreme Networks EXTR, -3.79% reported a fiscal second-quarter net loss of $5.6 million, or 5 cents a share, vs. a year-earlier loss of $19 million, or 17 cents a share. The results were in line with the company's expectations, and included research and development expenses related to a warrant issued Avaya. Net revenue fell 7.5 percent to $83.4 million, just above the average analyst forecast compiled by Reuters Research of $83 million. The high-speed network company's shares closed Wednesday down 9 cents at $8.95. Hibernia's Q4 profit exceeds Street consensus (7:42 AM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- Hibernia Corp. HIB posted a fourth-quarter profit of 46 cents per share, up from 41 cents earned in the final three months of 2002. Backing out one-time items, the New Orleans-based institution earned 49 cents for the latest quarter, ahead of the 45-cent analyst consensus as compiled by Reuters Research. Net interest income was essentially flat, coming in at $162.1 million for the latest quarter, although consumer and commercial loans both grew at double-digit rates compared to the 2002 period. Hibernia's assets increased 7 percent during 2003, reaching $18.6 billion as of Dec. 31. Shares of Hibernia added 22 cents to end Wednesday's trading at $22.97. IBM doubles profit, tops forecasts (corrected) (7:39 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- IBM IBM, -1.59% said fourth-quarter earnings rose to $2.7 billion, more than double the $1.02 billion the company earned in the same quarter a year ago. Operating earnings per share of $1.56, up from $1.11 per share a year ago, topped the analyst estimates of $1.50 per share compiled by Thomson First Call. Revenue was $25.9 billion, up 9 percent and beating estimates of $25 billion. Revenues grew at double digits in four of IBM's six industry sectors, the company said. "We enter 2004 with good momentum. The client buying environment is steadily improving," said CEO Samuel Palmisano. (Corrects income and comparison with last year.) National City restates results; Q4 EPS reaches 88 cents (7:26 AM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- National City Corp. NCC, -0.16% said it's restated results for the first three quarters of 2003 and for 2001 and 2002, in accordance with discussions with Securities and Exchange Commission staffers over the accounting of derivatives and hedging activities. Earnings for the fourth quarter came in at 88 cents per share, up from a restated 46 cents for the final quarter of 2002. The Cleveland-based institution's net interest income totaled $1 billion for the latest quarter, down 4 percent from the prior year. Along with the restatements, National City said it's modifying its effectiveness testing methods for 2004, an outgrowth of the discussions with SEC staff. Shares of National City rose 33 cents to end at $32.69 on Wednesday. Station Casinos reiterates Q4 earns view (7:13 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Station Casinos STN, -1.01% reiterated fourth-quarter earnings expectations, excluding non-recurring items, of 38 to 41 cents a share and its full-year forecast of $1.68 to $1.78 a share. The casino operator added that it expects to start developing Red Rock Station in Las Vegas in mid-2004 at an anticipated cost of $450 million to $475 million. The company expects Red Rock to add 6 to 11 cents a share to earnings in the first full year that it's open, and 25 to 31 cents a share a year by the third year of operations. The stock closed Wednesday up 51 cents at $32.91. Fifth Third Bancorp's Q4 EPS a penny better than Street (7:09 AM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- Fifth Third Bancorp FITB, -1.86% posted a fourth-quarter profit of 80 cents, a penny ahead of the Reuters Research-compiled consensus and higher than the 72 cents earned in the final three months of 2002. The Cincinnati-based institution's net interest income reached nearly $735 million in the latest quarter, up from $698.2 million a year earlier. Fifth Third's shares ended Wednesday's trading at $58.38, down $1.01. FleetBoston Q4 beats by 4 cents, on 7% revenue growth (7:01 AM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- FleetBoston Financial FBF, -11.49% posted a fourth-quarter profit of 68 cents per share, four cents better than Wall Street's consensus and higher than the 24 cents earned in the final three months of 2002. Revenue reached $3.067 billion for the latest quarter, up 7 percent from the prior year. "We fully expect to carry this momentum into 2004 and the pending merger with Bank of America," said CEO Chad Gifford. FleetBoston's total assets stood at $200.2 billion as of Dec. 31, up from $190.5 billion at the end of 2002. Quarterly results benefited from a sharp reduction in provision for credit losses. FleetBoston shares added 51 cents to end Wednesday at $43.08. Comerica Q4 earns down in line, 'recovery taking hold' (6:54 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Comerica CMA, -1.49% said fourth quarter earnings declined to $158 million, or 89 cents a share vs. $206 million, or $1.18 a share in the year-ago period. Analysts had forecast, on average, earnings declining to 88 cents a share, according to Reuters Research. "The quarter ended as we expected, given the challenges our customers faced as a result of the economy," said Ralph W. Babb Jr., chairman, president and chief executive officer, in a statement. "I believe we are now seeing the turn in credit quality and the business recovery appears to be taking hold." Union Planters misses by a penny on Q4 EPS (6:27 AM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- Union Planters UPC posted a fourth-quarter profit of 51 cents a share, down from the prior year's 68 cents and a penny shy of the consensus forecast among analysts surveyed by Reuters Research. The Memphis-based bank holding company also projected earnings for 2004 in a range of $2.25 to $2.40 per share, excluding charges related to plans for what it called a "rightsizing of our mortgage infrastructure" as well as office consolidation and a brokered home-equity provision. These charges are expected to amount to 18 cents to 22 cents. Wall Street's 2004 consensus stands at $2.41 per share. Union Planters said it experienced "a significant reduction" in mortgage banking revenue and earnings during the fourth quarter. Shares of Union Planters added 51 cents to end Wednesday's trading at $30.24. Bank America Q4 tops forecasts, bad loans recede (6:17 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Bank of America BAC, -1.97% topped expectations with fourth quarter earnings of $2.73 billion, or $1.83 per share up from $2.61 billion, or $1.69 per share, earned a year ago. Analysts had been looking for $1.77 a share, according to a Reuters Research poll. "Overall credit quality continued to improve. Net charge-offs and nonperforming assets continued to decline as a percentage of loans and leases. All major commercial asset quality indicators are showing positive trends while consumer credit quality performance remains stable," the bank said. Merrill Lynch shares inactive, firm sees record 2003 (4:37 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Merrill Lynch MER, -2.35% shares were not active in pre-open trade, London dealers said. The broker-dealer overnight announced it had alluded to a record year of profits in a note to employees. "The company said it expects to report record full-year net earnings. The previous record full-year net earnings were $3.784 billion, reported in 2000," it said. Merrill plans to release results for 2003 Jan. 21. Merrill ended up 1.5 percent Wednesday at $58.41. Handset retailer Carphone to top forecasts on strong Q3 (3:09 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- The Carphone Warehouse(UK:CPW), a U.K. mobile phone retailer, said it expects to top the consensus forecast for the year after third quarter sales exceeded expectations. Same-store retails sales in the thirteen weeks to Dec. 27 rose 27.7 percent. Connections grew 25.7 percent to 1.67 million. "Subscription connections growth accelerated again, stimulated by network competition and a vibrant handset market," the group said, adding it was "confident that the group will achieve a full year result ahead of current consensus market expectations." HMV music, books holiday same-store up 3% (3:03 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- HMV Group(UK:HMV), the British music, video and Waterstone books retailer, said same-store sales in the five weeks to Jan. 3 rose 3 percent. It added its gross margin in the period was ahead of 2002 "despite the highly competitive trading conditions." Looking ahead, it said: "the strong Christmas trading, coupled with pleasing performance in the first half, leaves us well placed to deliver our targets" for the year. Reuters Q1 subscriber revenue seen down 9% (2:44 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- British financial news and information provider Reuters Group(UK:RTR) RTRSY Thursday said it expects the decline in its first quarter recurring revenue, or subscriber sales, at 9 percent "or slightly better on an underlying basis" against the year ago period. The drop was in line with forecasts from analysts for a 7 percent to 9 percent decline, according to an AFX poll. Subscriber cancellations in the fourth quarter of 2003 improved over the third quarter, it said. "I am confident that we have now passed the inflection point in our recurring revenue decline," Reuters CEO Tom Glocer said. "While we still expect the recovery in recurring revenue to be gradual, we are looking forward to working with our customers to build on this improving trend." ASML beats on Q4 profit, Dunn to retire (2:32 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Dutch chip equipment maker ASML ASML, -2.06% (NL:33436)on Thursday said it swung to a fourth quarter profit of 16 million euros, more than anticipated, despite a sales decline from 91 systems and services at 820 million euro value to 43 new and 18 refurbished systems worth 526 million euros. Its order backlog increased in terms of number of systems to deliver, at 124, but the value was lower than a year ago at 993 million euros. It added that the Dutch workforce reduction has been delayed and, correspondingly, the results of cost reductions have been delayed. In addition, President and CEO Doug Dunn said he would retire before the end of the year, and the company will start searching for a replacement. For the full year, ASML's losses were pared to 160 million euros from 208 million. Samsung Electronics jumps on 24% Q4 profit gain (12:24 AM ET) TOKYO (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Samsung Electronics SSNGY, +0.00% erased losses and gained 1 percent to 499,500 won by midafternoon trade in Seoul after the South Korean semiconductor giant reported a 24-percent jump in net profits due to booming sales of chips and flat-panel displays. Samsung's net income rose to 1.86 trillion won ($1.6 billion) from 1.5 trillion won in the year-ago period. Analysts had forecast a profit of around 2 trillion won. The company also said in a statement that operating profits soared 63 percent to 2.63 trillion won in the quarter from 1.6 trillion won. Sales rose 22 percent to 12.9 trillion won in the quarter. content: Another holiday week means another respite from earnings-driven news. Luby's LUB, +0.72% a cafeteria chain with 144 restaurants, will report fiscal first quarter earnings on Tuesday. On Friday, Optical Cable OCC, -4.67% which supplies fiber optic cable for data, video and audio transmission, will post fourth quarter earnings. Biopure BPUR continued to drop after Friday's closing bell, shedding another nickel in after-hours trading. The biotech company said late Wednesday that it had received a "Wells notice" from the Securities and Exchange Commission indicating preliminary plans to recommend a civil injunction against the company. CIT Group CIT, -0.39% a commercial lender and insurer that was spun off from Tyco in 2002, is moving ahead with plans to cut debt costs and refocus its investments, says Barron's. A short ownership by Tyco tainted CIT's debt ratings yet Chief Executive Albert Gamper says its balance sheet was better after leaving Tyco than when it was purchased in 2001, thanks to $1 billion injected to help CIT drop underperforming investments. Now, says Barron's, CIT hopes to raise its performance by refinancing about $7 billion of long-term debt, saving $100 million a year. Also, the company's lending will expand to include leases of rail cars and equipment used by small businesses. One such venture already partners with Dell Computer to finance sales. Barron's says CIT shares trade at about 11 times estimated 2004 earnings compared to a 13 multiple for other financial companies in the S&P 500. Dyax DYAX, +0.00% a biotech drug developer, said late Friday that its DX-88 had positive results in Phase I and Phase II medical studies of patients who had heart-artery bypass surgery. Dyax said its study found no serious adverse reactions and said patients receiving DX-88 had lower need for blood transfusions. Farmer Jack, a Detroit-based division of grocery chain Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co. GAP, +2.27% said Saturday that union workers ratified a cost-cutting agreement that runs through June 2007. FAO FAOOQ the bankrupt toy merchant, said late Friday that it sold its landmark New York store and other properties for $20 million. See full story. IDT IDT, +0.64% which sells prepaid phone cards, could be underpriced if some of its ventures take off, according to Barron's. With shares closing Friday at $20.39, Barron's says the company's cash and equivalents total $12 a share. Most of that is from its 21 percent holding in Net2Phone NTOP and proceeds from shares of that company that were sold. IDT also has stakes in film and animation production, telecom hookups for businesses and a plan to wire money overseas via prepaid debit cards. Wall Street has withheld applause, says Barron's, because IDT is still posting net losses. But the company expects profitability starting in February 2004. Metropolitan Mortgage & Securities MPDPR and an affiliate, Summit Securities SGMPR both said late Friday that they will delist their preferred shares on the American Exchange so they can be traded over the counter. Summit said it will not file its 10-K annual report by a Dec. 29 deadline and expects to file it no sooner than Feb. 4 because it believes its losses were larger than reported in its June 30 10-Q filing. Metropolitan subsidiary Western United Life Assurance Co. WUCPR which said it had $1.7 billion in assets as of June 30, will be placed under voluntary supervision of the state insurance commissioner of Washington state to reassure policy holders and shareholders. Western United said late Friday that it will appeal an Amex delisting decision and plans to continue to pay dividends. On Nov. 3, Summit's board suspended dividend payments because it had $7 million in cash and capital needs of $10 million. According to the Metropolitan Mortgage & Securities Web site, all the companies operate under the corporate structure of the Metropolitan Financial Group of Companies. See full story. Mirant MIRKQ the Atlanta-based energy marketer that filed for bankruptcy in July, lost a legal request to reject two power-purchase contracts, according to a statement from Pepco Holdings POM, +1.79% issued after Friday's market close. Pepco said a subsidiary gained a favorable ruling from a federal judge in Fort Worth, Texas, requiring Mirant to honor terms of an accord because it had not received federal regulatory approval for any waiver. Under the legal injunction, Mirant will have a chance to argue against the ruling Jan. 5. Orchid Biosciences ORCH, -0.49% which conducts genetic tests for food safety, could see continued momentum as the impact from mad-cow disease becomes more clear. The stock continued its Friday-session advance after hours. Applied Digital Solutions ADSX which owns a majority stake in animal microchip maker Digital Angel DOC, -1.63% also followed through with a small gain after a regular session rally. Petrosearch PSC.P, +0.00% which acquires oil and gas property, said late Friday that it continues to negotiate with 4R Energy Lending L.L.C. for a $2 million unsecured line of credit, beyond the time frame the company had forecast earlier. Stolt-Nielsen SNSA a Norwegian-owned shipping and oil-service company, said late Friday that it gained an extension till May 21 from lenders over covenant defaults. The company, which is one of four shippers being sued by Dow Chemical over price-fixing allegations, said it will pay down $160 million on a credit facility by Feb. 29 and has until May 21 to pay a remaining balance of $140 million. Stolt-Nielsen said an offshore oil subsidiary has suffered "heavy losses" on construction projects off the coast of West Africa. SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) - Earlier this year, Jim Oberweis, Jr. couldn't drum up much interest among sullen investors for his aggressive small-growth stock mutual fund. But now the gloom is off the small-stock rose. "It's a whole 'nother world," says Oberweis, manager of the Oberweis Emerging Growth fund OBEGX, +1.07% "Buying profitable high-growth companies trading at reasonable valuations is very much in favor." Indeed, small-growth stocks are leading the charge in a snapback rally that many investors still can't believe is real. And some sharp-eyed small-growth fund managers have been enjoying the wild ride. "The money is being made in the small-cap stocks," says J. Taylor Brown, vice president at The Hirsch Organization, publisher of the Stock Trader's Almanac. "This isn't the end of the bull market; we haven't come full cycle yet." In just eight months, the Russell 2000 has gained 37.3 percent, while the Dow DJIA, -1.44% is up 26 percent. Small-cap growth stocks are experiencing an even stronger revival. While small-cap value held its own through the bear market - the Russell 2000 Value index gained a cumulative 25.4 percent in the three years ended in December - the Russell 2000 Growth index slid 62 percent in that same period. It's soared 40.3 percent since October, recouping more than a third of its bear-market losses. Investors should consider keeping about 15 percent of their portfolio in small-cap stocks, says Mark Balasa, a financial adviser with Balasa, Dinverno, Foltz & Hoffman in Schaumburg, Ill. He now recommends a 25 percent allocation, down from a recent 30 percent when small-caps were cheaper. Most individual shareholders are better off investing in small-caps through mutual funds, Balasa says. "It's a very inefficient market, and the premium in terms of real return can be given back by trading costs." With that in mind, we screened Morningstar's Principia database for the 15 small-growth funds with the biggest gains since the October market lows. To qualify, funds needed at least $1 million in assets and a retail shareholder base. Beyond that, all that mattered was absolute performance on a load-adjusted basis. The funds that passed this screen can be extremely volatile and are capable of stellar gains and stunning losses - such is the nature of small-stock investing. See related story. Even PBHG Emerging Growth is back on the top-performing list, up 45.1 percent since the October lows -- but in the three years through December it lost a total of 105.4 percent Top-ranked Polynous Growth A PAGFX is up 104.8 percent in the past eight months, but lost 40.7 percent in 2002. More tellingly, manager Kevin Wenck has 35 percent of this eclectic $8 million fund committed to a single stock: Optical Cable Corp. OCC, -4.67% which manufacturers fiberoptic cable to upgrade business systems. Shares have almost tripled year-to-date, but Wenck says Optical Cable still trades at roughly one-third the value of competitor Corning GLW, -2.19% Another 30 percent of the Polynous fund is in cash, when 10 percent is more typical. "Stocks hit target prices and they get sold, and nothing comes along to replace them," Wenck explains. "That's usually a pretty good indicator that maybe things have gone too far, too fast." Most small-cap funds broadly diversify across stocks and market sectors, if only to minimize the risk of any one investment going wrong. The Oberweis portfolio, for example, has about 60 holdings, spread among nine major market sectors, according to Morningstar. And for all the recent trouble Oberweis had attracting investors, it turns out that his fund has been one of the small-growth rally's best performers. "This is SO much fun," Oberweis writes in the current issue of the monthly Oberweis Report newsletter. The $87 million Emerging Growth fund is up 55.7 percent since the depths of the small-stock sell-off last October. Sibling Oberweis Micro Cap OBMCX, +1.68% recently closed to new investors after its assets surged above $90 million. And while some small-cap investors are turning cautious, Oberweis predicts that small stocks could be breaking out into a multi-year rally. As more buyers come into the market, he says, demand grows for a limited supply of shares. "The natural tendency is for this to fuel itself," Oberweis adds. "It becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy."
