content: Stocks to watch Tuesday CNet CNET, +3.07% confirmed Monday that it's laying off 5 percent of its workforce, or 80 employees. The online media company didn't provide specifics as to what jobs would be cut, or when the staff reductions would take place. The company did not comment beyond restating its goal to reach operating profitability in the fourth quarter. The company is set to announce results on Jan. 30, after the close of trading. The stock ended the regular session Monday up 1.8 percent. Intel (INTC: news, chart, profile) will report its fourth-quarter results after Tuesday's closing bell. Wall Street analysts expect a profit of 14 cents a share on sales of $6.92 billion. A year ago, the chip giant posted earnings of 15 cents a share on sales of $6.98 billion. Rambus RMBS, -1.71% earned 6 cents a share on sales of $25.7 million during its fiscal first quarter. Rambus said earnings were flat and sales increased 5 percent from the previous quarter. Varian Semiconductor VSEA said preliminary results indicate fiscal first-quarter earnings of 6 to 9 cents a share, instead of the breakeven results Varian had predicted. Sales were just above the midpoint of its projected range. Monday advancers AsiaInfo Holdings ASIA, -0.71% rose more than 16 percent after the company disclosed that it has secured a contract to provide enterprise information portal software to Tianjin Netcom, a unit of China Netcom. Financial terms weren't disclosed. Atmel ATML added more than 6 percent after the company said its chief financial officer, Donald Colvin, had resigned to pursue other opportunities. Robert Avery, the chipmaker's corporate director of finance, is to assume Colvin's duties until a permanent replacement can be found. Bionx Implants BINX soared almost 41 percent after the maker of implants for orthopedic applications said it had agreed to be acquired by Conmed CNMD, -1.99% for $48 million, or $4.35 a share. The bid represented a 45 percent premium over Friday's closing price, but a 29-percent discount to its 52-week high of $6.10. Conmed expects the deal to be financed from its revolving credit facility. It anticipates closing the deal in the next four months. Broadwing BRW, +0.82% rose nearly 8 percent after the company said financing commitments increased to $350 million from $200 million in the previous month, and said it has initiated discussions with its agent banks over a comprehensive amendment to the terms of its credit facility. The telecom services company said it was mulling the sale of its broadband unit. The company also confirmed expectations for revenue, EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) and capital investment. Cholestech CTEC, +0.73% advanced 28 percent after Adams Harkness & Hill boosted its rating on shares of the Hayward, Calif., provider of medical diagnostic testing products and services to "buy" from "market perform." The firm cited increasing profitability and better trends in its core business, and an attractive valuation relative to its peers. Chordiant Software CHRD rose almost 10 percent after Thomas Weisel upgraded the stock to "attractive" from "market perform," citing a clearer 2003 revenue outlook, continued success of its partnership with IBM IBM, -2.01% and expectations the company will reach cash-flow breakeven in 2003. Analyst Rob Schwartz said he expects deferred revenue and backlog to increase "because of seven-figure deals that closed at the end of the quarter." Coinstar CSTR, -4.06% jumped nearly 11 percent after the Bellevue, Wash., coin-counting firm said that earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization for its North American operations would come in at the high end of its range of $50 million to $51.5 million in 2002. The company sees 2002 revenue for North America at roughly $149.6 million. Earnings per share and net income from continuing operations for North America are projected at the high end of previous estimates of 95 cents to $1 per share, and $21.5 million to $23 million, respectively. Coinstar also said that it expects to record a fourth-quarter gain of $42.6 million, or $1.87 per share from its recognition of deferred tax assets. Covad Communications COVD gained almost 15 percent after Kaufman Bros. released a research note reiterating its "buy" rating on the shares. Kaufman said it expects Covad to pre-release operating statistics for the fourth quarter after Monday's closing bell, or Tuesday morning. The firm expects the company to meet its outlook for net subscriber additions of 20,000 to 25,000. It also believes Covad will beat its outlook for EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) of $25 million in the period. "Accelerating growth should attract a new round of investors to the stock, as growth has been a missing key ingredient to the Covad story without which the company cannot prove its model is viable," Kaufman said. Endwave ENWV rose more than 41 percent after the provider of radio frequency subsystems raised its fourth-quarter revenue outlook. The company now anticipates revenue of $6.6 million to $6.9 million for the quarter ending December, up from a previous forecast of $5 million to $6 million. France Telecom FTE, +0.55% rose more than 9 percent in Big Board trading after the company said it plans to issue 3 billion euro in bonds to reduce its need for government support. The stock also received an upgrade from Goldman Sachs to 'in-line' from 'under-perform.' Grand Toys International GRIN gained more than 6 percent after the company said its Canadian subsidiary signed an exclusive agreement to distribute Mayfair Stationary in Canada. The company plans to sell the arts and crafts products through mass market retailers and through office supply and art material stores. Next Level Communications NXTV rose more than 34 percent after Motorola MSI, -1.39% said that it plans to make a tender offer to acquire all the outstanding stock of Next Level that it doesn't already own. Motorola holds 74 percent of Next Level's common stock. The offer values Next Level shares at $1.04 each. Shares of Numerical Technologies NMTC, +0.00% leapt almost 87 percent after the provider of sub-wavelength integrated circuit technology announced an agreement to be acquired by Synopsys SNPS, -2.03% for about $250 million, or $7 a share in cash. That represents an 89 percent premium to Friday's closing price, but a 76 percent discount to its 52-week high ($29.75). Synopsys said it expects the acquisition, which is expected to close in the first quarter, to be dilutive to fiscal 2003 earnings by less than 10 cents a share, then accretive to fiscal 2004 results. Optical Cable OCC, -4.67% gained nearly 13 percent after the Roanoke, Va., fiber optic cable firm said that it has repurchased more than 21 percent of its outstanding common stock in a privately negotiated transaction. The company bought back 1,475,867 of its common shares from A.G. Edwards for $2 each, or $2.95 million. Sina Corp. SINA, -5.05% surged more than 5 percent after the wireless portal said it had entered into a three-year agreement to be Motorola's MSI, -1.39% strategic partner for a wireless site to serve mobile users in China. The agreement includes advertising commitments from Motorola and cooperation on wireless information and community functionalities in China. Financial terms were not disclosed. Talk America TALK, +0.00% gained almost 7 percent after the communications provider raised its fourth-quarter forecast for earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization (EBITDA) to a range of $16 million to $18 million, from $14 million to $16 million. The company also said revenue for the quarter ending December would be within expectations. Separately, the company said it anticipates recording an income tax benefit related to the reversal of a deferred tax valuation allowance of $20 million. Tenet Healthcare THC, -2.82% rose almost 5 percent after the company posted second-quarter earnings from operations of 72 cents per share, 3 cents ahead of the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Including items, the company earned $315 million, or 64 cents a share, up from its year-ago profit of $89 million, or 18 cents a share. Revenue rose 11.3 percent in the latest three months to $3.79 billion from $3.39 billion in the same period a year earlier. The company said, however, that its second-quarter results "are not indicative of what we expect beginning with the third quarter, given the new Medicare outlier policy we've volunteered to adopt as of Jan. 1. Looking ahead, the company forecast fiscal 2003 earnings of $2.40 to $2.60 per share, below its previous outlook for a profit of $2.38 to $2.78 per share. The lower outlook reflects the company's voluntary adoption of a new outlier policy last week and share repurchases. Monday decliners CryoLife CRY, -2.74% fell more than 6 percent after the company said that its interim agreement with the Food and Drug Administration has been renewed. The move allows CryoLife to distribute non-valved cardiac and vascular tissue processed prior to Sept. 5, 2002 for an additional 45 working days, or until March 20. For equivalent tissue processed since Sept. 5, CryoLife isn't required "to obtain physician prescriptions, label the tissue as subject to a recall, or require special steps regarding procurement agency records of donor screening and testing beyond those required for all processors of human tissue." The company said it continues to work with the FDA toward a full resolution of issues that led to the recall of certain tissue transplant products. Duke Energy DUK, -0.15% dropped almost 15 percent after the company warned that 2002 earnings would fall short of a previously given range due to the slump in the merchant energy sector and the economy overall. The company said in October that earnings for the year would be at the low end of the projected range of $1.95 to $2.05 a share, but now believes it will earn closer to $1.85 a share. The company added that 2003 earnings would come in between $1.35 to $1.60 a share, well below the average analyst estimate compiled by Multex of $1.84. Separately, the energy company said it would take total charges of approximately 65 cents a share for the year related to ice storm damage, restructuring and asset impairment. Georgia-Pacific GP, +0.00% lost nearly 8 percent after the company warned that continuing operations would break even in the fourth quarter. The suspension of production at some manufacturing facilities and competitive lumber pricing hurt results. Competitive market conditions and higher manufacturing costs also hurt its North American consumer products business. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting the paper company to earn 22 cents a share, on average, in the quarter ending December. Separately, G-P said it would take a charge of $315 million in the fourth quarter for asbestos liabilities and defense costs. Hibbett Sporting Goods HIBB, +0.21% fell almost 11 percent after BB&T Capital Markets lowered its rating on shares of the Birmingham, Ala., retailer to "buy" from "strong buy." The firm cited valuation for the move. The stock has rebounded in the past six months after sinking to a 52-week low of $16.66 on July 22. Immune Response IMNR dropped more than 12 percent after the Carlsbad, Calif., biopharmaceutical firm said that Ronald Moss plans to quit as president. Moss plans to take a job with Merck MRK, -1.40% Immune Response didn't immediately name a replacement. Motorola MSI, -1.39% slid almost 5 percent after Credit Suisse First Boston downgraded the stock to neutral from outperform and cut its price target to $8 from $11. "We believe the fundamental risks outweigh the potential rewards at the current valuation," CSFB said. Protection One POI lost nearly 8 percent after Westar Energy WR, -0.95% said it would explore strategic alternatives for divesting its investment in the company. Saks SKS, +0.75% gave almost 6 percent after the company was downgraded by J.P. Morgan to "underweight" from "neutral." The broker cited tough comparisons in 2003 and the stock's "full-looking" valuation. J.P. Morgan said it remained cautious on the department store chain's fundamental outlook, given its poor operating history and weak industry positioning. Standex SXI, +1.57% lost more than 8 percent after the Salem, N.H., manufacturing firm warned that it expects second-quarter results to be hurt the impact of a weak consumer market and soft holiday sales on its consumer group operations. The company now sees earnings of 29 to 33 cents a share in the period, including items. In the same period a year earlier, Standex earned 52 cents per share. "Revenues for the Consumer Group are down 10 percent for the quarter compared with the second quarter last year resulting in the projected earnings decline," said Roger Fix, the company's president, in a press release after Friday's closing bell. "We expect that the performance of our Industrial and Food Service Groups will be essentially flat for the quarter on a year-over-year basis." content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- When the lights turn on and the cockroaches scurry back under the linoleum, Kevin Wenck says he likes his chances. The lights haven't turned on just yet as Wenck's Polynous Growth Fund PAGFX with over $6 million in assets under management, has struggled with a 27-percent year-to-date pullback while the S&P 500 has shed 16 percent. Over the last three years, his fund has lost 8 percent while the S&P 500 has fallen nearly 2 percent. "Polynous' overall emphasis is on growth stocks," Wenck said. "There's a bit of an opportunistic/contrarian way of looking at the world. I take advantage of situations where the rest of the world is overreacting." His first pick, Optical Cable OCC, -4.67% makes up almost 20 percent of the fund. As Wenck pointed out, "You hear the words 'optical cable' and you feel like gagging? All you can imagine is the glut of cable running from Seattle to Chicago with 6 percent getting used." But the bulk of Optical Cable's revenue comes from internal enterprise usage in markets that seem to be doing just fine, he said. "The company has historically been profitable, it's always been cash flow positive, and it's had no debt." Its shares fell 5 cents to 56 cents on Friday. Next up, VeriSign VRSN, -1.98% While Wenck admits a chunk its business comes from the deteriorating market of domain registration, he likes the fact that two-thirds of sales stems from "plumbing the Internet and telecom systems." And that the stock has been "obliterated" only makes its case more compelling. Verisign fell 4 cents to $9.08. His last pick is Able Laboratories ABLA Wenck sees a bright future for this generic drug manufacturer as the company has 15 new drug applications on file that he says are "about to be acted on by the FDA." The last year and a half has been especially good for Able, as Wenck sees it. "The company was probably within a couple days of going out of business before the approvals started coming in." Its shares fell 6 cents to $5.60. content: Stocks to watch After the market closed, women's apparel retailer AnnTaylor Stores ANN reported fourth-quarter earnings of $9.95 million, or 34 cents a share, compared with the year-ago total of $5.1 million, or 18 cents a share. Sales totaled $371.4 million, compared with the year-ago total of $343.6 million. In addition, the company upped its targets for fiscal first quarter of 2002 to between 52 cents to 54 cents a share from its previous target of 48 cents to 52 cents a share. Analysts have been expecting a profit of 48 cents a share for the first quarter. Shares closed up $1.45 to $41 ahead of the news. Merrill Lynch shares were halted for late trading. The investment bank said MER it is considering a convertible offering of Liquid Yield Option Notes, or so-called LYONs. LYONs are zero-coupon floating rate notes that are convertible into Merrill Lynch common stock. They would not be callable for five years after issuance, and would mature in 30 years. Merrill said it would use the proceeds for general corporate purposes, and it's expecting to generate $1 billion from the offering. Shares closed the regular session up $1.10 at $54.40. After the market closed, arts and crafts retailer Michaels Stores MIK reported fourth-quarter net income of $63.6 million, compared with the year-ago total of $50.1 million, or 76 cents a share. Excluding one-time items, the company earned 96 cents a share, beating the consensus estimate by a penny. Sales totaled $908 million, up 11 percent compared with the year-ago period. Same-store sales for the quarter increased 6 percent. Shares closed up 45 cents to $34.15 ahead of the news Wednesday. Internet security and domain registration giant VeriSign said Wednesday its first-quarter results are poised to meet market expectations, even amid a weak business environment tied to ongoing sluggishness in corporate investment. CEO Stratton Sclavos said that results seem "on track," citing Wall Street's forecast of $340 million in revenue and earning per share pegged at 20 cents. In the fourth quarter last year, the company reported a loss of $401 million on sales of $284 million. Shares of VeriSign VRSN traded up 33 cents to end Tuesday's session at $29.34. See full story. Advancers American Eagle Outfitters AEOS added almost 9 percent after the company reported fourth-quarter earnings of $43.9 million, or 60 cents a share, down from its year-ago profit of $49.1 million, or 68 cents a share, but 2 cents ahead of the average view of analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call. Sales for the latest three months rose to $464.3 million from $423.7 million in the same period a year ago. Same-store sales fell 2.1 percent in the period. American Superconductor AMSC rose nearly 11 percent after the company received a $2.9 million contract from the U.S. Navy's Office of Naval Research. The deal calls for the Westborough, Mass., firm to provide its power electronic converter technology for use in intelligent, re-configurable systems to be developed by the Navy. Calpine CPN jumped almost 19 percent in late action, building on a roughly 12 percent gain in Tuesday's session. The California Public Utilities Commission Tuesday deferred until March 21 a vote on proposals to confirm the date that direct access was suspended in the state, according to Dow Jones. The dates in question are Sept. 20, the original date, and July 1. If the commission chooses July 1, contracts signed between July 1 and Sept. 20 would no longer be honored, said Dow Jones, which also quoted CPUC Commissioner Carl Wood as saying he would vote for July 1. Ceragon Networks Ltd. CRNT added more than 11 percent after the Israeli provider of high-capacity broadband wireless systems firm scored a deal to provide its FiberAir systems to Svenska UNTS Nat AB, a joint venture of Telia Mobile and Tele2. Financial terms of the multi-year frame agreement weren't disclosed. Chattem CHTT leapt more than 10 percent after the Chattanooga, Tenn., consumer products firm inked a definitive agreement to acquire the Selsun Blue medicated dandruff shampoo brand from Abbott Laboratories ABT for $75 million, plus inventories. The company noted that Selsun Blue's sales totaled roughly $41 million in 2001. The deal is expected to close in the second quarter. Chattem believes the acquisition will immediately boost sales and EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) and add to earnings per share. Checkers Drive-In Restaurants CHKR climbed more than 26 percent after the Tampa, Fla., firm reported fourth-quarter earnings of $2.3 million, or 18 cents a share, up from its year-ago earnings from continuing operations before items of $917,000, or 10 cents a share. Total revenue rose in the latest three months to $51.1 million from $44.1 million in the same period a year earlier. Same-store sales rose 4.1 percent for the period. Christopher & Banks CHBS surged almost 9 percent after the Minneapolis women's clothing retailer reported February same-store sales rose 2 percent. Total sales for the four weeks ended March 2 advanced 4 percent to $19.4 million from $18.6 million in the same period a year earlier. "We are encouraged that same-store sales were tracking to an increase in the mid-single digits through the third week of the month," said Bill Prange, the company's chairman and CEO, in a press release. "However, in the fourth week, same-store sales were negative as snowstorms impacted business in much of our market area." Prange went on to say that the company expects earnings to come in a penny shy of Wall Street's consensus estimate for a profit of 40 cents a share in the fourth quarter. For the first quarter, Christopher & Banks is looking for a same-store sales increase in the mid-single digits. Finlay Enterprises FNLY leapt nearly 15 percent after the company said that it expects earnings of $2.40 to $2.45 per share in the fourth quarter, and $1.75 to $1.80 per share in fiscal 2001. The New York fine jewelry retailer added that this revised outlook is above its previously disclosed expectations. "As a result of our better than expected sales in the fourth quarter and our focus on expense control, we exceeded our earlier profit forecast for the fiscal year," said Arthur Reiner, the company's chairman and CEO, in a press release. "In addition, our disciplined inventory management enabled us to generate significant free cash flow as we ended the year with about $49 million of cash versus $32 million at the prior year end." Fortress Group FRTG added almost 23 percent in afternoon action. Late in Tuesday's session, the McLean, Va., homebuilder reported fourth-quarter earnings from continuing operations of $5.7 million, or 54 cents per share, up from its year-ago equivalent profit of $2.3 million, or 18 cents a share. Revenue jumped 27.6 percent in the latest three months to $90.9 million from $71.3 million in the same period a year earlier. New orders, however, dropped 35.7 percent to 142 from 221 in the same period a year ago, reflecting a decline in the Denver/Fort Collins area, and continued softness in the Austin market. ImClone IMCL jumped more than 20 percent after the company and Bristol-Myers revised terms of their commercialization deal for the cancer drug Erbitux. Bristol BMY will have an expanded role in the clinical and strategic development of the cancer drug. Also, instead of a $300 million milestone payment, Bristol will pay ImClone $140 million in cash at the deal's signing and $60 million in cash one year after the signing. Further, Bristol will pay ImClone the originally agreed upon $500 million milestone payment, based on FDA approval, in two equal parts. ImClone will get a distribution fee based on a flat rate of 39 percent of North American product revenue. See full story. Leap Wireless LWIN soared more than 35 percent in afternoon action. Gabelli Asset Management disclosed in a filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission that it owned 8.75 percent of the wireless communications carrier's outstanding shares, up from the 7.73 percent it said it owned in a Feb. 26 SEC filing. On Tuesday, the stock soared 37 percent. A senior vice president at the company had told CBS.MarketWatch.com that he wasn't surprised, and couldn't understand why the stock was down in the first place. The stock had hit a 52-week low of $3.77 on Feb. 21, versus its 52-week high of $36.78 reached on May 2 of 2001. LodgeNet Entertainment LNET added more than 10 percent after the provider of broadband services for the hotel industry said that it's targeting first-quarter results at the upper end of its outlook for revenue of $51 million to $54 million, and EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) of $18 million to $19.5 million. Nortel Networks NT surged more than 6 percent after the telecommunications equipment maker clinched a $500 million deal to upgrade Cingular Wireless' mobile phone network in Puerto Rico and the southeastern part of the United States. Nortel said in a statement it would upgrade Cingular's GSM networks in North Carolina, South Carolina, coastal Georgia and eastern Tennessee, and switch the second biggest wireless carrier's network from TDMA to GSM in Puerto Rico, it said in a statement. Nortel said the upgrade would allow Cingular to boost voice capacity on its existing network by 120 percent. Optical Cable OCCF jumped more than 24 percent after the dismissal of two lawsuits against the Roanoke, Va., fiber optic cable maker. The lawsuits were filed by UBS PaineWebber, whose suit was dismissed with prejudice, and Bear Stearns, whose suit was dismissed without prejudice. The suits were related to Optical Cable shares that the brokerages sought to liquidate in order to cover personal margin loans they made to Robert Kopstein, the company's former chairman, president and CEO. Optical Cable had refused to authorize the transfer of the shares, saying that the brokerages had already sold sufficient stock to cover Kopstein's liabilities. In addition, Optical Cable said that A.G. Edwards and Scott & Stringfellow are the only brokerages still holding its common shares as security for loans to Kopstein. These firms hold in total 16.2 million shares of Optical Cable stock. In addition, the company said that first-quarter sales totaled $11.4 million, down from $17 million in the same period a year earlier. " Sorrento Networks FIBR climbed more than 14 percent after the San Diego optical networking firm said that it received cash proceeds of $13.6 million from the merger of NetSilicon and Digi International DGII In addition, Sorrento received 2,325,000 million shares of Digi common stock, a roughly 11 percent stake in the company. Sprint FON jumped nearly 9 percent after the company said it was "on track" to meet its financial targets for 2002 while detailing the first-quarter outlook for both its PCS PCS and FON Groups. Full-year projections for the wireless PCS Group include the addition of 3 million customers and EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes and amortization) of $3 billion. Sprint, meanwhile, expects 700,000 to 750,000 net customer additions in the first quarter and EBITDA to approach around $600 million, excluding one-time charges associated with the closing of five customer care centers. Sprint reaffirmed 2002 goals for the FON Group, including EBITDA of around $4.6 billion and earnings-per-share approaching $1.40. Thomson Financial/First Call projects 2002 EPS of $1.31 for Sprint Corp. US Airways U rose more than 5 percent after the company named David Siegel as its president and chief executive. Stephen Wolf, the airliner's chairman, had been acting CEO following the resignation of Rakesh Gangwal in November. Siegel was most-recently chairman and CEO of Avis Rent a Car, a subsidiary of Cendant CD Prior to that, he had spent seven years at Continental Airlines CAL See full story. Western Multiplex WMUX gained almost 12 percent after the company rejected an unsolicited acquisition offer from DMC Stratex Networks STXN choosing instead to stick with original merger partner Proxim PROX DMC Stratex shares rose more than 10 percent, while Proxim's stock jumped almost 19 percent. Decliners Camtek Ltd. CAMT plummeted almost 25 percent after the Israeli developer of automated inspection systems for circuit board production reported a fourth-quarter loss of $2.9 million, or 13 cents a share, wider than the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call for a loss of 6 cents. In the same period a year earlier, the company earned $3.6 million, or 16 cents a share. Sales dropped 54.6 percent in the latest three months to $7.3 million from $16.1 million in the same period a year earlier. The company noted that margins deteriorated to 41.6 percent in the quarter from 54.9 percent in the same period a year earlier due to a shift in product mix to basic systems with weaker margins and continued pressure on prices. Looking ahead, Camtek warned that it's "not yet seeing a real improvement in sales" and that its revenue outlook for the first quarter is within a range of $4 million to $5 million. Conseco CNC tumbled more than 15 percent after Moody's issued a press release cautioning investors "about the implications of Conseco failing to demonstrate the certainty of its cash generation plans by March 31, 2002." Moody's went on to say that it believes Conseco will need to provide its independent auditors PriceWaterhouse Coopers with a "viable plan" that shows its ability to meet all of its obligations in 2002 in order to receive an unqualified opinion on its financial statements for 2001. Moody's said that if Conseco doesn't receive the unqualified opinion, it will most likely downgrade its credit ratings "2 or more rating notches," adding that "there remains little room for error should the plans not proceed according to schedule." In addition, the company announced that Chuck Chokel has resigned as chief financial officer. DoubleClick DCLK slumped almost 8 percent after Morgan Stanley downgraded the online advertising firm's stock to "neutral" from "outperform." Analyst Michael Russell said he sees "no near-term fundamental catalyst" to drive the shares, which he noted has reached his price target. He estimates the stock is worth $12 to $13 each. See full story. Hycor Biomedical HYBD gave nearly 46 percent after the maker of diagnostic equipment for medical applications said it was no longer in discussion with any potential buyers of the company. "While we are disappointed that no acquirer was found, we are continuing to hold discussions relating to possible product distribution arrangements, both worldwide and regional, as well as developing alternative business strategies as we go forward as a stand alone entity," said J. David Tholen, Hycor's CEO. Joule JOL dropped more than 8 percent after the company said that business conditions in January and February were softer than the same period a year earlier, leading it to forecast second-quarter revenue of 5 to 6 percent less than last year's total of $19.5 million. This will produce "marginal results" for the quarter, according to the Edison, N.J., staffing firm. "We are encouraged by recent signs of increased business activity; however, we do not anticipate that March revenue will sufficiently offset the shortfall of the prior two months," said John Wellman, the company's president and COO, in a press release. "We continue to rationalize costs throughout the organization and are optimistic regarding indications that the macro-economic environment is improving, making us more hopeful regarding the year's second half." Liberate Technologies LBRT tumbled more than 11 percent after Deutsche Banc Alex Brown lowered its rating on shares of the San Carlos, Calif., maker of television services software to "market perform" from "buy." The firm cited a slowdown in the company's business in the U.K., and the risk that Liberate will need to close major deployment deals in order to deliver on its outlook. Deutsche Banc said that a substantial trial deployment by Cox Communications COX is already well known and likely priced in, removing a potential positive catalyst. The firm sees Liberate as "fairly valued" and it assigned a price target of $7 per share. "Should the company win major new deployments soon, we would expect to see a rally, however, beyond Cox, we are cautious and note that the U.S. cable industry remains focused on VOD (video-on-demand) and high speed data this year," Deutsche Banc told clients. McData MCDTA plunged more than 28 percent after the company said it expects a first-quarter loss of 2 cents to 4 cents a share on revenue of $73 million to $78 million. The storage networker's previous targets were for earnings of nil to 2 cents a share on revenue of $85 million to $95 million. McData cited a continuous cautious approach to IT storage and related infrastructure investment spending so far this year. Also, McData said its order pipeline remains strong and is consistent with targets. Gross margins are expected to be 42 to 44 percent. Actual results will be reported on April 17. See full story. ResCare RSCR sank almost 9 percent after the Louisville, Ky., provider of services for disabled people reported fourth-quarter earnings before items of 11 cents a share. Including charges totaling $22 million from reserves for accounts receivable and insurance claims, the company lost $10.6 million, or 44 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $2.3 million, or 10 cents a share. Revenue rose in the latest three months to $229.7 million from $223.3 million in the same period a year earlier. ResCare said that, as a result of its charges in the latest quarter, it was no longer in compliance at year end with certain covenants of its bank lending agreement. The company said it has started talks that it believes "will lead to a resolution of those variances." Looking ahead, ResCare said that it expects revenue growth of 4 to 6 percent in 2002 and earnings of 65 to 70 cents a share in the period. Ticketmaster TMCS slumped more than 5 percent despite the company's Citysearch online unit reporting a 23-percent increase in unique users to 5.7 million for January. The company added that page views rose 28 percent to 104 million. However, Analyst Lanny Baker at Salomon Smith Barney downgraded the stock to "neutral" from "buy," saying that it had put on a "great show" of late, but current valuation is "makes encore tougher." He feels more confident in the company's fundamentals but noted that the shares had surpassed his $27 price target. Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks to watch: Ann Taylor, Merrill Lynch and more

content: Stocks to watch Commerce One said Monday it forecasts a per-share loss for the third quarter, excluding charges, of 24 cents to 25 cents a share while revenue should range between $80 million to $83 million. The Net software company said sales have been hurt by "poor economic conditions." Analysts on average expected a loss of 23 cents a share on revenue of $90.6 million, according to First Call. Shares (CMRC: news, chart, profile) closed down 8 cents to $2.81 ahead of the news. Chaska, Minn.-based Entegris reported a loss of 2 cents a share in the fiscal fourth quarter as the chip market remained broadly depressed. Analysts polled by First Call expected the company, which makes sure that semiconductors are protected as they're processed and handled, to lose a penny a share in the most recent quarter. Entegris, which just ended its first year as a public company, reported revenue of $52.7 million, a decrease of 35 percent from the $81.3 million posted in the third quarter. Shares (ENTG: news, chart, profile) closed down 25 cents to $7.25. Fair, Isaac & Co. said it will meet or beat its per-share earnings target of 56 cents for the fourth quarter, which ended in September. Revenue is expected to be $88 million to $90 million. Analysts expected earnings of 55 cents a share, on average. During the same quarter last year, Fair, Isaac earned 39 cents a share on revenue of $78.7 million. The San Rafael, Calif.-based company makes credit scoring systems through statistics-based predictive tools. Shares (FIC: news, chart, profile) closed down $1.70 to $37.80. Marimba said its third-quarter net loss will be 13 cents to 15 cents a share on revenue of $10 million. Excluding charges, pro forma net loss will be 10 cents to 12 cents a share. Four analysts had expected a loss, excluding charges, of 10 cents a share, on average, within a range of 6 cents to 14 cents. According to a statement, fallout from Sept. 11 "resulted in the delay of a number of anticipated orders for the quarter." Marimba will cut expenses by $1 million, which will include some staff reductions. Shares (MRBA: news, chart, profile) closed up 6 cents to $1.28. Nordstrom JWN, -1.40% said after the markets closed Monday that same-stores sales declined better than 9 percent in September. The fashion retailer said sales were lower by 6 percent to $398.5 million in September compared to last year's $424 million. They might have been worse. Nordstrom - known for only a few but effective sales - threw an unprecedented Fall Sale that began Sept. 28 and ended Monday and helped boost sales. Subtracting those last three sales days of the month, the results were grimmer still. For the Sept. 1-27 period, Nordstrom (JWN: news, chart, profile) same-store sales plunged 15.2 percent and total sales sank 11.2 percent. In a press release, the Seattle-based concern said the plummeting sales "reflected a challenging retail environment made worse following the events of Sept. 11." In another uncharacteristic move, Nordstrom said it will hold a short conference call Tuesday to discuss the company's recent and planned near-term actions, and to update its third-quarter projections before the Nov. 15 scheduled release. Shares closed down 52 cents, or 3 percent, at $15.46 ahead of the news. Rent-A-Center warned investors about its third-quarter financials, approved a stock buyback and said its top executive has retired, effective immediately. Shares (RCII: news, chart, profile) were slated to reopen from a trading halt at 5:40 p.m. Shares ended the day down 20 cents to $25. For the third quarter, Rent-A-Center expects earnings of 50 cents to 52 cents a share on revenue of $433.5 million. Comparable store sales grew 4.6 percent. Analysts expected earnings of 66 cents a share, on average. In-store sales promotions decreased gross margins and increases in labor and advertising expenses hurt earnings. Chairman and CEO J. Ernest Talley, 66, will retire and director Mark E. Speese, 44, will take over both of Talley's positions. Speese previously was a vice chairman, the president and the chief operating officer at the Plano, Texas-based company. During the next 10 days, Rent-A-Center will buy back $25 million in stock owned by Talley at a minimum price of $20 a share and a maximum price of $27. Varian warned investors its fourth quarter net income will be 28 cents to 30 cents a share on revenue of $187 million to $190 million. Shares (VARI: news, chart, profile) closed down 20 cents to $25.11. Excluding charges, net income is pegged at 32 cents to 34 cents a share. Four analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call expected earnings of 38 cents or 39 cents a share. According to a statement, transportation-related delays hurt the company's Scientific Instruments unit and weak capital spending hit the Vacuum Technologies unit. Varian makes scientific tools, high-vacuum pumps and provides contract manufacturing services. Advancers Shares of the Ackerley Group AK gained nearly 22 percent after the company said it has agreed to be acquired by Clear Channel Communications CCU, -0.88% in a stock deal valued at approximately $800 million, including the assumption of $294 million in debt. Clear Channel shares fell nearly 3 percent. Atlas Air CGO, -0.21% shares rose nearly 10 percent after Bear Stearns raised its rating on the Purchase, N.Y., air cargo transportation services firm to "attractive" from "neutral" due to an increased demand for its services. The firm noted that it recently raised its rating on Atlas to "neutral" from "unattractive" because it expected an upswing in freighter capacity demand. The analyst continues to think demand will increase because freighter capacity will grow as passenger capacity declines, increased security will require airlines to fly less freight in belly spaces, and the military will use Atlas Air cargo planes to fly support missions for troop movements. The firm characterized its opinion as a "trading call for short term aggressive investors to buy CGO." ECI Telecom Ltd. ECIL advanced more than 9 percent after the company said that the business of its Enavis unit was hurt by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. The Israeli telecommunications networking firm also cited the general market conditions in the U.S., which represents a major market for Enavis. The company now expects revenue of $16 million to $17 million from Enavis in the third quarter, down from revenue of $30.5 million in the second quarter. As a result, the company forecast revenue of $250 million to $255 million for the third quarter. This includes a contribution from its recently sold Business Systems unit. But ECI did add that it saw improved cash flow and increased cash balances during the quarter, making additional borrowing unnecessary. FindWhat.com FWHT gained more than 19 percent after the New York Internet advertising services firm said it expects earnings of 2 cents a share on revenue of $5 million to $5.5 million, in the third quarter and a profit of 4 cents a share on revenue of $5.5 million to $6 million in the fourth quarter. The company forecast revenue of $30 million in full year 2002, up 67 percent from its projected 2001 total of $18 million. Earnings for 2002 are pegged at $4.5 million, or 23 cents a share. Helen of Troy Ltd. HELE, -3.22% jumped 5 percent after the El Paso, Texas, marketer of personal care products reported second-quarter earnings of $7.3 million, or 25 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $3.7 million, or 13 cents a share. Sales jumped 29 percent in the latest three months to $113.5 million from $88.2 million in the same period a year earlier. The company attributed the improved sales of its Epil-Stop and Spray products, Dr. Scholl's massagers, Sunbeam and Sable hair care appliances, Karina and Nandi hair care accessory products, and increased sales in its Professional unit. Helen of Troy raised its second half earnings outlook to 82 to 92 cents a share from 80 to 90 cents a share. It boosted its sales projection for the second half to $410 million to $425 million from $400 million to $415 million. Loudcloud LDCL surged nearly 9 percent after the company disclosed that Chairman Marc Andreessen purchased 438,000 common shares in the open market during in the months of September and October. ON Technology ONTC reversed earlier losses to close up more than 7 percent. The company warned that it expects third-quarter sales to be at or slightly above its second-quarter total of $5.7 million. The Waltham, Mass., remote software firm said it experienced slower sales in September due to delays in completing contract negotiations in both Western Europe and the U.S. ON was looking for revenue of $6.5 million in the third quarter. Looking ahead, the company expects revenue of $6.4 million to $6.5 million, which would put it at or near break even on a per share basis. For 2002, On is forecasting year-to-year growth of 25 percent, which would allow it to turn a profit for the year. Qualcomm QCOM, -3.75% gained more than 7 percent after analyst Mark Roberts at First Union Securities reiterated his "strong buy" on the stock, saying the recent declines had created an "unusual opportunity at compelling valuation." The stock's decline began to accelerate last Thursday, when Nextel NXTL abandoned its plan to deploy a CDMA network. Looking forward, Roberts feels the news flow for Qualcomm should be more positive than negative. StangStat Medical SANG advanced more than 11 percent after the company forecast improved quarterly numbers. The Fremont, Calif.-based biotech firm anticipates a third-quarter loss of between 3 and 5 cents a share, narrower than previous guidance of between 7 and 9 cents a share. SangStat cited strong therapeutic revenues and successful cost-cutting measures as the main contributing factors in the improved financial situation. "While we remain confident that our products will continue to gain market share in the quarters ahead," said CEO Jean-Jacques Bienaime, "at this time we are maintaining our previously reported financial guidance for the remainder of the year which includes near-term profitability." TeleCorp PCS TLCP gained more than almost 35 percent after AT&T Wireless AWE, +5.26% has agreed to buy the remaining 77 percent stake of the company that it doesn't already own for $2.4 billion in stock and assume $2.1 billion in net debt and about $221 million in preferred securities. AT&T Wireless said it will offer TeleCorp PCS shareowners 0.9 shares of AT&T Wireless common stock for each share of TeleCorp PCS common stock. The price is a premium of 19 percent based on the average of the closing prices for the past 30 trading days for TeleCorp PCS common stock. AT&T Wireless shares pulled back more than 3 percent. TriPath Imaging TPTH rose more than 37 percent after the Burlington, N.C., cancer screening and diagnostics products company said it has received approval from the Food and Drug Administration to include the screening of its AutoCyte PREP thin-layer preparations on the AutoPap primary screening system. "We are very pleased to have received FDA approval to screen AutoCyte PREP slides with the AutoPap System," said Paul Sohmer, the company's president, chairman, and CEO, in a press release. "We believe that the clinical performance and economic efficiencies gained with our integrated solution offer the flexibility that our customers require as they transition from conventional testing to thin-layer Pap smear testing." Vysis VYSI jumped nearly 13 percent after the company said that it expects to beat its previously disclosed outlook for recurring operating earnings of 3 to 6 cents a share in the third quarter. The Downers Grove, Ill., developer of DNA-based clinical products that provide information for genomic disease management said it experienced "record" sales of its core genomic products, particularly its breast, bladder, and leukemia/lymphoma cancer tests, and its prenatal and ASR/research products. Decliners AOL Time Warner AOL dropped more than 6 percent after Barron's published comments on the company from a short seller in the stock over the weekend. Doug Kass, manager of hedge fund Seabreeze Partners, noted that weakness in advertising impacts just about every facet of AOL's business, and that the company could face dilution from its AOL Europe joint venture with Bertlesman if that company decides to exercise a put option to exit the operation. See full story. Avigen AVGN fell almost 28 percent after the Alameda, Calif., biotechnology firm said that the clinical trial studying its Coagulin-B gene therapy for the treatment of hemophilia B is on clinical hold. The company said that this step was required by the protocol if the vector is identified in the semen of a patient. Avigen said it expects the study to start up again after an "appropriate period of time" after the disappearance of the vector from the semen. "The one patient treated to date is doing well and no significant adverse events have been identified," the company said. Bio-Technology General BTGC lost more than 12 percent after the company said it expects to report pro forma earnings of 5 to 6 cents a share in the third quarter. Product sales for the first nine months of the fiscal year are projected to come in between $70 million and $71 million, yielding pro forma earnings per share of 32 to 33 cents a share. In addition, due to a de-stocking initiative with distribution partner Gentiva, the company expects sales of its Oxandrin drug to Gentica to be lower than recognized in the first half of the year. The companies also amended their agreement to ensure that supplies of Oxandrin "more properly reflect end-user demand on an ongoing basis." Bio-Technology Group said that a federal appeals court has re-instated a Genentech DNA, +1.56% patent for a method of producing recombinant human growth hormone and placed an injunction against a product made by Bio-Technology using a similar process. "While we are disappointed with the decision of the appellate court," said Sim Fass, the company's chairman and CEO, in a press release. "We have every intention, by utilizing our new expression system, to supply Teva with hGH for the anticipated introduction of its Tev-Tropin hGH product in the United States in 2002." Luminent LMNE plunged more than 33 percent after the terms of the Chatsworth, Calif., fiber optics firm's short-form merger with MRV Communications MRVC were announced. The deal calls for MRV to swap each outstanding share of Luminent for 0.43 of an MRV common share. MRV plans to offer up to 5.16 million common shares in the deal. The deal remains subject to certain regulatory approvals. Shares of MRV, which already owns 92.3 percent of Luminent, rose more than 1 percent. Nextel Communications NXTL dropped more than 9 percent after Merrill Lynch lowered its rating on the company's shares to "neutral" from "accumulate," saying that the company still needs to execute over the next few quarters in a tough economic environment and address longer term strategic issues. Merrill estimate the stock's value lies somewhere between $8 and $18 per share. Optical Cable OCC, -4.39% plunged almost 44 percent after the Roanoke, Va., firm said that a temporary restraining order obtained by its Chairman and CEO Robert Kopstein against various brokerage firms has been lifted. This order had prevented Salomon Smith Barney, Merrill Lynch, UBS Warburg, Bear Stearns, A.G. Edwards, Scott and Stringfellow, from selling Kopstein's personal holding in Optical Cable to satisfy personal margin loans with the firms. The companies and Kopstain will hold a mediation meeting on Oct. 10 but the firms are no longer prevented from selling Kopstein's shares. Optical Cable said the individual firms hold various numbers of shares, ranging from 1.5 million and 15 million shares. The company said it has been notified that certain firms plan to sell the shares immediately, and it estimates that as many as 8.5 million shares of its common stock could come to market as early as today. Optical Cable also said that it has liquidated its investment in the Nasdaq 100 tracking stock QQQ, -3.15% netting proceeds of $1.6 million. Also, Thomas Brock resigned from the board as of Oct. 4. The Profit Recovery Group PRGX, -2.65% plummeted more than 33 percent after the company warned that third-quarter results would be lower than previous forecasts, saying its operations were "severely disrupted" by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. The provider of recovery audit services anticipates reporting earnings of 4 cents a share on revenue of $71.8 million during the quarter ending in September, while analysts surveyed by Multex had been expecting earnings of 14 cents a share on revenue of $84.6 million, on average. The company added that as of Sept. 30, it was not in compliance with certain financial covenants in its bank credit agreement, and will pursue covenant relief from its bank syndicate. SunTrust Banks STI, -2.91% lost nearly 6 percent in afternoon action. Analyst Richard Bove at Raymond James attributed the stock's poor performance to fears that the bank has made major commitments to the airline industry. With the company slated to report results on Wednesday, Bove believes investors are anticipating a potential write-down similar to that of U.S. Bancorp USB, -2.20% which saw its stock tumble 16 percent on Friday. U.S. Bancorp fell another 8 percent Monday. The company had said Friday that it would record a wider-than-expected after-tax provision for loan losses of $655 million in the third quarter Zoran ZRAN fell almost 11 percent after C.E. Unterberg, Towbin lowered its profit estimates for the firm due to declining DVD sales in North America. The firm maintained its "buy" rating on the company's shares but reduced its price target on the stock to $28 from $40. Third-quarter revenue remains at $30 million, but earnings estimate were cut to 13 cents a share from 14 cents due to an anticipated drop in gross margin to 35.5 percent from 36 percent. C.E. Unterberg cited the latest data from the Consumer Electronics Association in DVD shipments to U.S. retailers through the month of September and channels checks that indicate a slowdown in DVD sales. content: Stocks to watch Allegiance Telecom (ALGX: news, chart, profile) reported preliminary third-quarter results. The competitive local-exchange carrier reported preliminary third-quarter revenue of $135 million and an EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) loss for the quarter of roughly $26 million. Analysts, on average, currently expect third-quarter revenue of $147.2 million, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. Allegiance lowered its 2001 revenue target, which it said will be 5 percent lower than the previous expectation of $550 million. It held its 2001 earnings target steady. It expects 2002 revenue of at least $800 million, with cash flow break even in the second half of 2002, as previously expected. Shares closed down 13 percent at $4.42 ahead of the report. Corel. Corp. (CORL: news, chart, profile) reported third-quarter net income of $500,000, or 1 cent per share, compared with a net loss of $10.7 million, or 15 cents per share, for the same period last year. The two analysts reporting estimates to First Call both pegged the company to earn 2 cents per share. Revenue declined to $34.2 million from $36.4 million for the same quarter last year. The company said cash, cash equivalents and marketable securities at the end of the quarter stood at $123.8 million, vs. $11.6 million at the end of the third quarter of 2000. Corel shares finished trading off 5.4 percent at $2.09. See full story. Guitar Center warned that its third-quarter sales and earnings will fall short of expectations, citing a slowdown in sales since the Sept. 11 terror attacks. Guitar Center (GTRC: news, chart, profile) said sales for the third quarter are expected to be approximately $219 million to $222 million, with earnings per share between 4 and 6 cents. Analysts, on average, currently expect earnings of 16 cents per share for the third quarter, according to First Call. Shares closed down 1 percent at $10.87 ahead of the warning. Sonus Networks (SONS: news, chart, profile) expects a third-quarter net loss of 5 cents to 7 cents a share, excluding charges, on revenue of $40 million. Analysts had expected earnings of 1 cent a share, on average, on revenue of $54.4 million, according to a survey conducted by Thomson Financial/First Call. Also, for the quarter ended on Sept. 30, Sonus will take a charge of $435 million to write off goodwill, as well as a charge of $31 million for restructuring costs. For the year, Sonus, a maker of telecom products, expects revenue of $170 million to $180 million and a net loss of 8 cents to 10 cents a share. Ahead of the report, shares ended down 85 cents, or 12 percent, to $6.40. See full story. Advancers Autologic Information International AIII soared more than 115 percent after Agfa Gevaert NV's U.S. unit agreed to acquire all of Autologic's outstanding stock for $7.13 per share in cash, or $42.5 million. Volt Information VOL owner of 59 percent of Autologic, announced the deal, which is expected to close by year-end. Volt shares edged up 5 cents. Bed, Bath & Beyond BBBY, -2.50% gained more than 9 percent after the company reported a fiscal second-quarter profit above that of a year ago as sales increased by 21 percent. Union, N.J.-based Bed, Bath & Beyond posted earnings of $54 million, or 18 cents a share, vs. $43.6 million, or 15 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call expected the retailer to earn an average of 18 cents a share in the most recent quarter. Revenue grew to $713.6 million from $589.4 million in the fiscal second quarter of 2000. Christopher & Banks CHBS advanced almost 12 percent after the company reported second-quarter net income of $5.3 million, or 31 cents per share, compared with net income of $4.2 million, or 25 cents per share, in the same period a year earlier. Analysts, on average, were expecting earnings of 31 cents per share, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. Sales rose 39 percent to $57.8 million from $41.5 million. The company said sales were hurt from Sept. 11 until Sept. 14 but have rebounded. Christopher & Banks sees September same-store sales increasing 3 to 5 percent. Constellation Brands STZ, +0.40% tacked on nearly 5 percent after the company disclosed a public offering of 2.15 million of its class A common shares at $38.75 each by the Sands family. The company expects the offering to close on Oct. 1. Constellation granted the underwriter of the offering an over-allotment option to purchase up to 322,500 additional class A common shares. Proceeds from the over-allotment option would be used to repay debt. IMPATH IMPH rose more than 7 percent after the company warned that the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks will reduce third-quarter earnings of 3 to 4 cents a share. The revenue impact of the attacks is expected to be a reduction of $1.5 million to $2 million. Prior to the attacks, the New York cancer diagnostic technology firm said it was on track to meet Wall Street expectations for a profit of 27 cents a share on revenue of $46.8 million. Impath also said it would record a charge of $650,000 in the quarter related to the restructuring of its clinical trials business. Ivax IVX, +14.29% added almost 12 percent after the Miami pharmaceutical firm acquired two intranasal steroid brand products, Nasarel and Nasalide, from Elan ELN, +0.00% The products are for the treatment of seasonal and perennial allergic rhinitis. Financial terms weren't disclosed. Ivax plans to market the products in the U.S. through its Wakefield Pharmaceuticals unit. Elan shares are up $1.83, or 4 percent, to $47.62. Separately, Analyst Gregory Gilbert at Merrill Lynch said Ivax moved to reassure investors in a conference call that its business was performing well and that shipment problems have been resolved. The company also said it expected third quarter revenue of approximately $340 million, above Gilbert's forecast of $327 million. Standard Commercial STW, +0.00% rose nearly 6 percent after the Wilson, N.C., tobacco dealer said it expects second-quarter basic earnings per share of 85 to 95 cents a share, well above "the current public estimate of 42 to 44 cents a share." Analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call are currently looking for a profit of 44 cents a diluted share. The company maintained its estimate for a profit of $1.85 per basic share for the full year, noting the unsettled economic outlook in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Tyson Foods TSN, -6.05% rose 13 percent after the Springdale, Ark., chicken producer said that it expects fourth-quarter earnings of 18 to 22 cents a share, well above its previous outlook for a profit of 8 to 12 cents a share in the period. The company said the projection doesn't include the acquisition of IBP IBP, -3.25% which Tyson expects to complete by the end of the week. Vans VANS jumped more than 5 percent after the company reported first-quarter net income of $11.3 million, or 61 cents per share, compared with net income of $7.1 million, or 48 cents per share, in the same quarter a year earlier. Analysts, on average, were expecting earnings of 57 cents per share. On the top line, sales rose 17 percent to $118 million from $100.6 million. "Our thinking as of now is that we will be modestly profitable in the second quarter with total revenues flat to down approximately 5 percent," said CEO Gary H. Schoenfeld. Analysts are currently expecting earnings of 18 cents per share for the second quarter, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. For the third quarter, Vans sees sales increasing 15 percent and earnings per share increasing 30 to 35 percent compared with the third quarter last year. For fiscal 2002, the company sees earnings per share roughly in line with 2001 with a roughly 10 percent rise in sales. Decliners Adept Technology ADTK lost almost 28 percent after the company warned fiscal first-quarter revenue would fall due to continuing cancellations and order delays. The company said the slowdown was "compounded" by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Revenue is now expected to fall 30 percent to 40 percent from the previous quarter's sales level of $20.7 million. Based on those percentages, revenue should be about $12.4 million to $14.49 million. Adept had expected sales to fall only 10 percent to 20 percent. The company, which previously implemented a cost reduction plan, is "evaluating additional measures." AES Corp. AES, -0.26% plunged nearly 50 percent after the company slashed its forecast for full-year earnings per share to a range of $1.25 to $1.45, citing the weakening Brazilian real, falling electricity prices in the U.K. and tepid economic growth. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call expected the Arlington, Va., power firm to earn $1.78 a share this year. Read full story. Cambrex CBM, -0.48% dropped more than 12 percent after the East Rutherford, N.J., life science firm warned that results for the third and fourth quarter would miss Wall Street expectations. Cambrex expects a profit of 27 to 32 cents a share in the third quarter, and 30 to 40 cents a share in the fourth quarter. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call are currently looking earnings of 44 cents and 50 cents in the respective periods. The company cited weak economic conditions, which have diminished demand for specialty and fine chemicals, animal health and agricultural products. It added that its human health operations were weaker than anticipated and that all of its businesses were hurt by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Cambrex remains confident that it will return to double-digit earnings growth in 2002. CMGI CMGI fell 16 percent after the company said its fourth-quarter loss ballooned to more than $1 billion as revenue declined 30 percent from the same period a year ago. CMGI said its loss widened to $1.3 billion, or $3.70 per share, from $635 million, or $2.17 per share, in the year-ago quarter. CMGI, which invests in and operates a host of Internet companies, said revenue declined to $256 million from $370 million last year. excluding certain charges, CMGI said it had a fourth-quarter loss of $104.5 million, or 30 cents per share. Comverse Technology CMVT slumped almost 13 percent after analyst Victor Halpert at Salomon Smith Barney downgraded the stock to "neutral" from "buy," cut his price target to $27 from $50 and sliced his financial estimates for fiscal 2002 and 2003. "Recession fears, lower consumer spending and high penetration rates of key mobile markets may affect Comverse Technology's growth," Halpert said in a note to clients. Corn Products International CPO, -2.86% fell nearly 6 percent after the Bedford Park, Ill., corn refiner reduced its earnings outlook to $1.65 to $1.75 per share from $1.95 to $2.05 per share. This projection includes a gain of 10 cents a share from an income tax refund net of restructuring charges. The company said it had been within its expectations prior to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, which have affected volumes and weakened currencies around the world. In response, Corn Products is slowing production at U.S. plants to reduce working capital and be better positioned for 2002. For the third quarter, the company said it still expects to earnings to come in about 25 percent above its performance in the same period a year earlier. Actual third-quarter results are scheduled for Oct. 16 Digi International DGII, -1.21% dropped more than 9 percent after the Minnetonka, Minn., connectivity software firm lowered expectations for its fourth-quarter results. Digi expects to report earnings excluding items of 1 to 4 cents per share on sales of $26 million to $28 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call were looking for a profit of 8 cents a share in period. The company said its results were hurt by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and the uncertain economic environment. Digi is recording a charge of $3 million, or 12 cents a share from the discontinuation of its DataFire product line in the quarter. In addition, the company said that it's unable to publicly forecast revenue or earnings for the next quarter at this time due to lack of visibility. Eclypsis ECLP dipped almost 7 percent in afternoon action. After Tuesday's closing bell, the Delray Beach, Fla., healthcare information products firm said it may see a delay in new sales bookings in the third quarter due to travel disruptions related to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Bookings are projected between $50 million and $85 million. The company said anywhere from five to seven major contracts could be delayed. Still, Eclypsis said it remains comfortable with expectations for third-quarter earnings of 12 to 14 cents a share and that it believes the delayed contracts would close in the fourth quarter Encompass Services ESR, +16.28% sank 15 percent after the Houston provider of energy facilities systems and services warned that results for the third and fourth quarters will be "significantly below our previous expectations." The company withdrew its outlook for revenue, earnings and EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization) for the rest of the year. Encompass cited a continued lack of revenue visibility "caused by an uncertain economic environment and exacerbated by world events." In addition, the company said it's ceasing operations of its global technologies group effective Sept. 30, citing the weak outlook for capital spending on colocation facilities, telecom hotels, and Web hosting centers. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call are looking for profits of 24 cents a share in both third and fourth quarters Massey Energy MEE, -0.85% lost nearly 19 percent after the Richmond, Va., coal producer said that production and shipment issues may affect its ability to meet earnings projections for the fourth quarter. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call are looking for a profit of 16 cents a share in the period. Massey said production levels have been hurt by the performance of inexperienced miners, and transportation delays due to increased enforcement of West Virginia trucking laws. The company also noted that talks have been terminated on a coal property transaction that was projected to close during the quarter. Massey didn't provide a specific estimate of its results. Maxtor Corp. MXO, +13.04% dropped almost 11 percent after the company warned that it expects to report a third-quarter pro forma loss of between $85 million and $95 million, corresponding to a loss of about 36 to 40 cents a share. The Milpitas, Calif.-based supplier of information storage products sees third-quarter revenue coming in at around $1 billion. Thomson Financial/First Call had expected a loss of 24 cents a share on revenue of $1.17 billion. The shortfall was blamed on lower-than-expected unit shipments. Micron Technology MU, -4.00% sank nearly 19 percent after the company reported a fourth-quarter loss of $576 million, or 96 cents a share, on revenue of $480 million. During the same quarter last year, net income was $726.7 million, or $1.20 a share, on revenue of $2.3 billion. Excluding a charge of $118 million, or 20 cents a share, for an equity investment write down, Micron's loss was $458 million, or 76 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call expected a loss of 34 cents a share, excluding the 20-cent-a-share charge, on revenue of $694 million. Optical Cable OCC, -4.39% plunged almost 38 percent. The company addressed the substantial decline in its stock price and the increase in trading volume of late. The Roanoke, Va., firm disclosed that Chairman and CEO Robert Kopstein "has pledged a significant amount of his personally-held Optical Cable Corp. stock to various brokerage firms as security for substantial margin loans." With the decline in the company's stock, several of the firms began selling the pledged securities. Optical Cable said that Kopstein sold 358,100 shares in August, 288,100 shares of which were offered to meet margin calls. The selling has continued into September, the company confirmed, but the number has not yet been compiled by Optical Cable. As for its buyback program, the company said it has repurchased 818,500 of its shares for $6.75 million from Aug. 1 to Sept. 20. Beyond Sept. 20, it hasn't bought any stock but it could revisit that decision in the future. NRG Energy NRG, -0.43% sank nearly 9 percent despite the company saying it remains "on course" to meet its previous 2001 earnings estimate of $1.35 per share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call are currently expecting EPS of $1.37, on average. David Peterson, NRG's chairman and chief executive, also addressed investor concerns about exposure to Latin America and the United Kingdom. Peabody Energy BTU, +0.47% slid more than 6 percent despite the St. Louis firm's disclosure before the opening bell that it expects earnings for the current calendar quarter to exceed previous expectations. The company is now forecasting a profit from continuing operations of 5 to 10 cents a share for the quarter ending Sept. 30, better than a prior outlook for a loss. EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization) is pegged at $80 million to $85 million. The company previously targeted EBITDA of $79.5 million. Peabody said it's seeing strong coal industry fundamentals and that it has a large percentage of business committed for 2001, 2002, and 2003. The company also reaffirmed expectations for earnings of $2.00 to $2.30 per share in 2002, with EBITDA of $500 million to $520 million Primedia PRM, +0.00% dropped more than 38 percent after the New York media firm warned that it expects third-quarter earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization of $33 million to $36 million. For the full year, the company expects to report EBITDA of less than the $250 million reported in 2000. Primedia said it cannot at this time quantify the impact of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the economy, the general brand advertising market and its business at this time. The company continues to forecast improvement in 2002, saying that its new media losses will dramatically decline, its magazine group has been re-engineered, EMAP USA will improve its EBITDA, and that consumer endemic advertising continues to show strength. Earlier in the session, the stock plumbed a 52-week low of $2.96. Redback Networks RBAK plunged more than 21 percent after the company warned that third-quarter results will miss estimates. The maker of optical networking equipment used in metropolitan markets said the terrorist attack on Sept. 11 exacerbated "an already weak" telecom-equipment market. The company said it will take steps to "significantly" cut costs, though it did not issue specifics. For the third quarter, Redback said it now expects to post sales of $35 million to $40 million. Read full story. Resources Connection RECN, -7.41% slid more than 9 percent after the Costa Mesa, Calif., provider of international professional services reported first-quarter earnings of $4.3 million, or 19 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $2.2 million, or 13 cents a share, and a penny ahead of Wall Street expectations. Revenue jumped 25 percent in the latest three months to $48.9 million from $39.2 million in the same period a year earlier. The company did caution investors, however, that the rest of the year "will continue to be a challenge because of uncertainties caused by a slowing U.S. economy and the recent terrorist attacks." Resources Connection plans continue to monitor expenses carefully because of these uncertainties. The company noted that it was able to reduce general and administrative expenses to 26.3 percent from 27.4 percent of revenue year-over-year in the latest quarter Saba Software SABA, +0.00% dropped more than 29 percent after the company reported a first-quarter net loss of $11.2 million, or 25 cents per share, compared with a net loss of $19.1 million, or 46 cents per share, in the same quarter a year before. It reported a pro forma net loss of $5.4 million, or 12 cents per share, compared with a pro forma net loss of $14.1 million, or 34 cents per share, in the same quarter a year before. Analysts, on average, were expecting a loss of 14 cents per share. SKECHERS USA SKX, -1.58% fell almost 11 percent after the company said that it expects third-quarter revenue to be at or above the top end of its range of $265 million to $275 million, up from $205.7 million in the same period a year earlier. But third-quarter earnings are expected to be in-line with or slightly below its year-ago profit of 40 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call are looking for a profit of 51 cents a share in the period. In addition, in light of current economic uncertainty, SKECHERS believes it may fall short of Wall Street's consensus estimate of 31 cents a share. The company said that high sales in July and August "taxed" its existing infrastructure, creating additional costs in these months. Then, when the weak retail environment and the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks slowed down September shipments, the company was unable to reduced planned spending for the month. SKECHERS is re-evaluating its infrastructure spending and plans to cut costs. Textron TXT, -2.20% tumbled nearly 24 percent after the company lowered its second-half financial expectations and expanded its restructuring program as a result of the slowing U.S. economy and the impact of the Sept. 11 events. The diversified industrial company now expects a loss of 25 cents per share, excluding charges, in the third quarter and earnings of 40 to 60 cents a share in the fourth quarter. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call had been expecting profits of 71 cents and $1.05 per share, respectively. United Rentals URI, -3.44% slumped 11 percent after the Greenwich, Conn., equipment rental firm lowered its outlook for the second half due to the slowdown in the economy, particularly in the western U.S. For the third quarter, United Rentals expects earnings of 62 to 67 cents a share on revenue of $790 million to $810 million. Fourth-quarter earnings are projected at 32 to 37 cents a share on revenue of $700 million to $730 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call had been forecasting profits of 80 cents and 49 cents, respectively. Actual results are expected on Oct. 25. Vascular Solutions VASC fell 58 percent after the Minneapolis firm said that it has shifted its marketing focus to its Duett sealing device following the cancellation of the Transcatheter Cardiovascular Therapeutics meeting. The company also forecast sales of $2.5 million for the third quarter, saying that the summer slowdown in catheterization procedures and the maturing of the vascular sealing device market made it difficult to add new accounts. Sales rose to $3.5 million in the second quarter. Winn-Dixie Stores WIN, -3.90% plummeted more than 37 percent after the Jacksonville, Fla., grocery store chain lowered its first-quarter earnings expectations to 15 to 18 cents a share from 24 to 30 cents a share. For the year, the company now expects a profit of $1.05 to $1.20 per share, down from a previous outlook of $1.60 to $1.75 per share. Second-quarter earnings are pegged at 27 to 33 cents a share. Winn-Dixie cited uncertainties in the timing of the full benefits of its restructuring and general business and economic conditions. In addition, the company said it would shift its dividend payment policy to quarterly in arrears from monthly in advance in order to improve its financial flexibility. Winn-Dixie said future dividends will be paid on a "financially prudent" level, which it anticipates will be 20 cents per share on an annualized basis. Earlier in the session, the stock scraped a 52-week low of $13.
